title: rishi sunaks stamp duty holiday
story: Rishi Sunaks stamp duty holiday sparked buy to let bonanza and blow to first time buyersLabour analysis found the number of buy to let mortgages tripled after the chancellor announced the tax cut in his  budget Image: REUTERSByMikey SmithWhitehall Correspondent:,  Oct Updated:,  Oct | commentsRishi Sunak’s stamp duty holiday has led to a bonanza for buy to let landlords - and a blow to first-time buyers, research has found. Labour analysis found the number of buy to let mortgages tripled after the chancellor announced the tax cut in his  budget.Last July, Mr Sunak announced that the zero rate would be increased from £  to £ . But the discount applied to landlords and second homeowners, and analysis of figures from UK Finance shows that buy to let mortgages tripled from   when the holiday was announced in July , to   in June  when the biggest discount came to an end. Meanwhile, the proportion of mortgages to first time buyers was down every month from October  to June . In March and April , the months before the holiday was first expected to end, the proportion of mortgages to first time buyers was down % on the previous year.  Labour’s Shadow Housing Secretary Lucy Powell said: “The Conservatives have wasted millions of pounds on a stamp duty holiday which benefitted landlords and second homeowners, over first-time buyers trying to get a foot on the ladder. “Rather than seeing homes as the bedrock of a stable and successful le, the Conservatives treat housing as a commodity to be traded and profited from.”  First time buyers lost out in every region. In the South West, mortgages to first time buyers were down % on the previous year in April . In the North West, they were down % in March , and the East and West Midlands were down % in the same month. Ms Reeves added: “Labour is the true party of home ownership. Rather than robbing first-time buyers of their advantage, we would give them first dibs on new build homes, and stop the scandal of developments being sold off plan to overseas investors.” A Treasury spokesperson said: “Our temporary stamp duty cut helped to protect hundreds of thousands of jobs which rely on the property market by stimulating economic activity.” Comment MORE ON Labour PartyConservative PartyFirst-time buyersMortgagesStamp dutyPolitics" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get UK politics insight with our free daily email briefing straight to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: top tory oliver dowden turned
story: Exclusive: Top Tory Oliver Dowden turned down electric limo to keep gas-guzzling JaguarHis predecessor, Amanda Milling was driven around in an electric I-PACE Jaguar until she lost her job as party co-chair in September’s reshuffle - but Mr Dowden opted to keep the car and driver he had at DCMS Image: AFP via Getty ImagesByMikey SmithWhitehall Correspondent:,  Oct | commentsTory Chairman Oliver Dowden turned down an electric limousine to keep his gas guzzling Jaguar, the Sunday Mirror can reveal. His predecessor, Amanda Milling was driven around in an electric I-PACE Jaguar until she lost her job as party co-chair in September’s reshuffle. But just a month before the UK hosts world leaders at the COP climate conference in Glasgow, Mr Dowden opted to keep the petrol-powered car and driver he had in his previous job as Culture Secretary. A Tory source said: “Amanda Milling went for an electric car when she was offered as she thought it was important for the Conservative party chair to do their bit for the environment ahead of COP. “But Oliver clearly doesnapost feel the same. When he arrived at CCHQ he asked for a petrol one instead.” But a spokeswoman for Mr Dowden said: “He has a lovely driver and just wanted to keep working with him. Someone has got the wrong end of the stick.”  As Minister without Portfolio, Mr Dowden’s limousine is provided by the Government Car Service at taxpayer expense. Drivers come with a specic car, and while some ministers retain their driver and car when changing departments, not all do. Mr Dowden’s spokeswoman said he had “just kept same drivers from [his former department] as many ministers do when they move.”  In June, Mr Dowden helped launch the Tech Zero Taskforce at the CogX tech conference in London. He told attendees: “I hope this marks a turning point in our fight against climate change – and it’s right that the tech industry leads the charge.” But Mr Dowden has voted against a string of opposition motions in the Commons calling on the government to make commitments to tackle the climate crisis. title: vaccine centres mount half term
story: Vaccine centres to mount half-term Covid- jabs blitz for - year oldsNHS chief Amanda Pritchard has ordered  sites to get kids vaxxed with online appointments opening on Friday Image: REUTERSByMikey SmithWhitehall Correspondent:,  Oct | commentsVaccine centres are to mount a half-term jabs blitz on  -  year olds in a bid to curb the alarming rise in school cases. NHS chief Amanda Pritchard has ordered  sites to get kids vaxxed with online appointments opening on Friday. And tomorrow . million letters will begin landing on parents’ doorsteps urging them to book in. Schools have been able to vaccinate nearly , pupils but rates among secondary children are higher than they were in January Deputy head of the NHS vaccine programme Dr Nikki Kanani said: “October half-term is a convenient time for parents to get their children vaccinated. “I urge families to give children crucial protection ahead of winter.”  Parents and s will have to accompany sons and daughters so they can give consent for the jabs to go ahead.Health Secretary Sajid Javid said: “This will further support the vaccine rollout to build our wall of defence.”The NHS booster programme has now delivered third doses to . million adults while three in five - and -year olds have had their single dose.  Mr Sunak will also pump £million into training adults to improve their maths in a bid to fill one million job vacancies. Jane Gratton of the British Chambers of Commerce said: “More needs to be done to close the skills gap and improving numeracy sits at the very heart of that.” Comment MORE ON NHSBoris JohnsonHalf TermPrivate jetsPoliticsCoronavirusCoronavirus vaccine" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get UK politics insight with our free daily email briefing straight to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: boy 15 turns ocd business
story: Boy, , turns OCD into business for celebs including Gary Neville and Molly-MaeZykiah Ditchett, from Worsley, Salford, Greater Manchester, was diagnosed with obsessive compulsive disorder at the age of  after concerns were raised over his “constant” cleaning at homeZykiah Ditchett with Love Islands Molly-Mae HagueByPaige Oldfield:,  Oct Updated:,  Oct | commentsA teenager with OCD has turned his condition into a business washing cars for celebrities including Gary Neville and Molly-Mae Hague. Zykiah Ditchett, from Worsley, Salford, Greater Manchester, was diagnosed with obsessive compulsive disorder at the age of  after concerns were raised over his “constant” cleaning at home. In a bid to get him outside more, his family bought him a car valeting set for Christmas and he used his kit to clean relative’s cars, being paid £ each time. Eventually, the schoolboy askedhe could clean neighbour’s vehicles.His mum, Jo Ditchett, put a post in a local Facebook group explaining Zykiah’s love of cleaning cars.She asked anyone who wanted their car cleaning to leave their vehicle outside the family home. Just hours after the post went live, cars lined the quiet street as dozens turned out to show their support. Speaking to the Manchester Evening News , Jo, , said: “We had a queue of cars down the close and down the next street. “Everyone jumped on and supported him. He did it that well they asked to come back. “He was charging a fiver but everyone was giving him £.” It didn’t take long for a local businessman to offer Zykiah a permanent base to work from. Jason from Coal and Cotton Gin Bar reached out to the family saying they were “really impressed” by his work. They offered him a canopy outside the venue at weekends to clean local cars. Two years on, Zykiah, now aged , runs his own social media accounts and website.The youngster now cleans for the likes of huge stars including former Manchester United defender Gary Neville, Love Island couple Molly-Mae Hague and Tommy Fury, and United footballer Scott McTominay. Jo continued: “He cleans for some Love Island stars.“It’s all from his social media. “Anyone who has a high-performance car comes to him but he does all cars. “And he’s all self-taught, he’s never done a course. He’s done it all online and designed his own flyers. “A lot of young lads message him asking how he started and he says with a bucket and sponge. “He had a bucket and sponge for the whole year before he knew how to use a valeting kit.“He went on Instagram, YouTube, any channel he could to watch the process.” Zykiah’s business, called DirtClean Manchester, charges £ for an outside and winter washes, mini valets for £, full valets for £ and king valets for £.One day, the year  pupil hopes to one day own a car valeting company in his own name and aims to have branches across the UK. Jo continued: “I feel so proud of him. We support him fully. “We know he’s going to do well and continue.” Comment MORE ON Gary NevilleTommy FuryLove IslandOCDMolly Mae Hague" data-immediate"data-immediate"Stay up-to-date with all the news from the Love Island villa this summer with our regular newsletterSign me upInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: chelseas first black player says
story: Exclusive: Chas first black player says own fans abused him and little has changed  years onPaul Canoville was signed up in  at the age of . From his first match he endured a torrid of racist abuse which continued for three years - but  years later black footballers still suffer on and off the pitchEx-Cha player Paul Canoville says social media means players can be abused  ByLorraine King:,  Oct Ex-footballer Paul Canoville was on the edge of his seat as he watched the penalty shootout at the finals of the Euro . The nail-biting last minutes of the match would determineEngland would win their first major football tournament in  years. When black players Marcus Rashford, Jadon Sancho and Bukayo Saka all missed their penalties Paul said he knew what would happen next. As Chaaposs first ever black player he was subjected to a catalogue of racist abuse which was so vile that he thought about walking off the pitch and never ing. Four decades on and the -year-old grandad said he knew Rashford, Sancho and Saka would have to endure the same but this time it wouldnapost just be on the pitch - it would be on social media.  He told the Mirror: At least with the abuse I faced it was at the match and once I finished playing football I could forget about it. But now social media allows black footballers to be abused   with very little done to stop it. When it comes to racism it has moved from the terraces to social media. This is the new  for racism in the sport and more needs to be done to wipe it out. Paul spoke to the Mirror exclusively after police made  arrests in connection with racist abuse towards the three black players back in July. The accused ranged in age from  to .  Chief Constable Mark Roberts, National Police Chiefsapos Council football policing lead, said: There are people out there who believe they can hide behind a social media profile and get away with posting such abhorrent comments. They need to think again - we have investigators proactively seeking out abusive comments in connection to the match and,they meet a criminal threshold, those posting them will be arrested. Paul told the Mirror: Taking a penalty is not an easy thing to do so for these three young players to receive abuse like this is sickening. But it has been going on for far too long.In , Paul signalled a welcoming change in football after being signed to Cha as black footballers at the top were far and few between. Cyrille Regis, Laurie Cunningham and Brendon Batson, who all played for West Bromwich Albion and were affectionately known as aposThe Three Degreesapos, were among the small number of black players. Paul was not only the same age as Bukayo at the time but both grew up in Southall in west London so he resonates with the talented teenager. Saka is just  and from the same neck of the woods as me so I understand where heaposs coming from and itaposs a big thing to be representing his country at such a young age, he said. What happened to Saka and the others shows nothing has changed since the s when I was on the pitch but then racism isnapost just a football thing - itaposs a society thing.  Recalling the first time he was subjected to racist abuse, Paul said he was unaware of the clubaposs aposhistoryapos and he was full of pride when he ran on to the pitch for the first time. My belly was chewing me up as I was so nervous, he said.I heard shouting and then I realised they were shouting at me. We were playing against Crystal Palace so I thought it was their fans trying to put me off but then I realised it was from the Cha terraces.They were shouting n***er go home, calling me a golliwog and some even threw bananas at me. I was shocked. Everyone could hear what they were saying and no one said a thing or asked me how I was until my manager consoled me.  That was the beginning of the horric racist abuse Paul faced from his own fans whenever he played for his team. He said: It was at both home and away games and no one called it out. It was like it wasnapost happening as people just buried their heads in the sand. The National Frontwere big and firm back then. They would be outside the stadium giving out leaflets and no one dared to say anything.  I especially hated it when I was at home at Stamford Bridge as the fans would really give me hell. All I would hear is n****r go home. I remember one time I scored the first goal and the racist fans said it didnapost count because it was scored by aposthe n****rapos. This went on for three years and it affected my performance which meant I had to play twice as good as the other players. I must say that it was only a minority of fans but enough of them to smash my confidence. But, I had to play lip service and get on with it otherwise Iaposd be seen as the aggressor.  Paul said the turning point finally came when his team were playing Sheffield Wednesday in the Milk Cup and they were losing -. He explained: I was sitting on the subs bench and was called to the pitch. I scored two goals and thataposs when the racist fans were silenced. I hardly heard any chants after that. After leaving Cha, Paul played for Reading where he said he was welcomed by fans there with open arms.  It was very multicultural there so I wasnapost subjected to the same racism but you speak to any black footballer and they will have a story to tell you, he said. I really want to see something done now. Itaposs been  years since I had racist abuse hurled at me and it still continues today albeit on social media. These social media companies really need to take more responsibility. I knew that the minute those three players missed their penalties the racist abuse would come in thick and fast.  Fans have stopped throwing bananas on the pitch but they are doing the equivalent on social media websites. Enough is enough. Paul is also calling for more to be done to stop people using anonymous accounts to target black players. There needs to be some sort of identication process, he said . If you go to open a bank account you need proof of who you are so why canapost the same be asked for social media accounts  We need to make sure there is no  available for racists to target footballers like this. Paul is now using his ugly experiences on the pitch to help the next generation overcome any obstacles they may face. In  the dad-of-nine set up the Paul Canoville Foundation which aims to empower children and teach them more about the importance of ersity.  This includes Paul hosting workshops in schools where he delivers anti-bullying messages and gives talks to youngsters on how they can boost their confidence. He said: My foundation is very important to me. I want to ensure the next generation is strong and able to cope with issues like racism as it is sadly very much a part of our society.For more information about Paulaposs foundation visit paulcanovillefoundationMost ReadDont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterMORE ON Racism" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: clever music genre combines metal
story: Clever music genre combines metal and maths and uses algorithms in its songsMaths is everywhere, it’s even in specic genres of music like ‘mathcore’ - a subgenre of hardcore punk and metal coreThe Dillinger Escape Plan are a prime example of the mathcore genre Image: GettyByEmily Sleight:,  Oct | commentsIt’s safe to say that maths really is everywhere, with algorithms involved in pretty much everything itaposs hard to escape the subject of numbers. But what about music  Well, the genre of music called ‘mathcore’ is dedicated to the world of mathematics and is all about aposbreaking boundariesapos. Described as a ‘subgenre of hardcore punk and metalapos, bands that fit into the genre usually emphasise complex rhythms. They do this through things like irregular time signatures, tempo changes, polymeters, angular melodies and peculiar chord possessions. Mathcore emerged in the s, and is displayed in bands like Converge, Coalesce, Botch, The Dillinger Escape Plan and Candiria. When describing ‘maths rock’ one Reddit user hit the nail on the head by saying: “It uses odd asymmetrical time signatures or constantly changing meters based on ious groupings of two and three. “Critics in the late s would describe this sound as mathematical and thataposs how it got its name.” Night In At Tiananmens, a mathcore band from Billings, Montana, aren’t shy to the unique genre, it’s their main focus, along with ‘grindcore’. Although the option to play mathcore music wasn’t a choice at first, drummer JR Anderson explained that they’d grown to aposlove the genre.apos He said: “I had been writing songs for what would become NIAT because I loved it. I wanted the intensity of grindcore but with the complexity of someone like The Dillinger Escape Plan. “In Montana, there isn’t anyone doing what Night In At Tiananmens is doing. NIAT has been around for three or four years now and during that time I’ve really grown to understand what mathcore is.Maths-Whizz is a super clever virtual maths tutor which delivers interactive games, lessons and exercises for five to  year olds.To see how good it is at transforming home learning for parents, weaposve negotiated an exclusive % off price to make it £. for the first month.Seeyou like it first and sign up to a -day no-obligation free trial by you can do that here. If you want to sign up for a month at a time or even a year, you can do that here but donapost forget to use the promo code aposMATHSapos.  So, what exactly drew the band to mathcore JR continued: “I believe, it’s a community of people who like a challenge. “In one way or another. I love playing this stuff knowing that I’m just a measure or note away from losing it. I get a rush playing this way.” The features of mathcore like tempo changes, aren’t just found in mathcore either, they’re also found in free jazz and ‘math rock.’ Mathrock isn’t as heavy as mathcore, and is described as a ‘progressive and indie rock’ displayed in bands like Coheed and Cambria and King Crimson. One Reddit user, describing the mathematical music genres, said: “Instead of going --- ---, it goes ------ ------.” Seems simple enough. title: dad who didnt realise men
story: Dad who didnt realise men could get breast cancer given devastating diagnosisGordon Allen from Swinton, Manchester, says at the time there was little information out there on male breast cancer - hes now speaking out to raise awareness it can happen to menGordon Allen who was diagnosed with breast cancer Image: suppliedBySaffron OtterDanya BazaraaSenior News Reporter:,  Oct Updated:,  Oct | commentsA dad who didn’t realise men could get breast cancer has shared how he was hit with a shock diagnosis. Gordon Allen, , was rushed to Salford Royal in an air ambulance in  after suffering an asthma attack, but when doctors saw his chest they did further tests. He said he couldnapost believe it when he got his diagnosis of stage two breast cancer. At the time Gordon was  and says there was little information out there on male breast cancer.He told the Manchester Evening News his boss even questioned it until he saw paperwork.Gordon, from Swinton, Manchester, is now speaking out about his diagnosis in a bid to make men aware that it can happen to them as well as women.He is speaking out as part of the Men Get Breast Cancer Too campaign from charity Walk the Walk this male breast cancer awareness week. Eight months before his asthma attack, Gordon, who has one daughter with his we Jayne, noticed changes to his left nipple. He felt pain, it had inverted and it had begun to crumble. “I didn’t go to the doctors to get it checked,” he told the Manchester Evening News. “I thought it looked odd, particularly when it went hard and started to flake. “But there was no publicity back then, it was the last thing I thought it was. “It might seem strange but I never knew men could get it and so it never occurred to me that’s what it was.” Despite being fit to go home from the hospital a few days later following his asthma attack, Gordon was aware something wasn’t right when they made him stay. He underwent a mammogram and biopsy and was then told the shocking news. “Once I got to the hospital, they took one look at my chest and hit the roof,” Gordon said. “They weren’t saying a great deal to me but my sister was an orderly nurse at the hospital – she did a bit of asking around for me and I got the impression from her that there was potentially something serious going on with my breast. “When they eventually told me, I couldn’t believe it. But I felt fairly calm about it.” Gordon credits this outlook to his Christian faith, feeling that it was up to God whether he lived or not, as well as a male nurse that helped him. “When everyone had left, I couldn’t help but just stare at the ceiling, I couldn’t get my head around it. “But this wonderful male nurse came and said to me, ‘well you know what it is now, the next thing is treatment.’ “And I thought, ‘he’s right. There’s no point getting all worked up, let’s get on with it and seewe can get it dealt with’.” Gordonaposs close friends and family were supportive of what he was facing but he says he felt stigma over his condition from his boss in the motor trade. Within  days of being diagnosed, he had a mastectomy to remove his breast and had to have time off from his job. “I hadn’t worked there very long which didn’t help,” Gordon continued. “He wouldn’t [his boss] believe it until I brought the paperwork in. He questioned, ‘you’ve got breast cancer  Men don’t get breast cancer. I’ve never heard of that’. “And then when I went back to work after my breast op, he never spoke to me again. Just passed by me and never talked to me.” Gordon didn’t need chemotherapy or radiotherapy and recovered well from the surgery, however was put on hormone therapy Tamoxen. In the months to follow, Gordon learnt the reality of how rare it was to have breast cancer as a man, and still to this day hasn’t met another man in person with the same condition. In the UK, around  men are diagnosed with breast cancer each year, and around  of these men will die each year. That’s almost a quarter at  per cent. As with women, it usually affects older men aged  and above, however it can be found in men of any age, like Gordon in his mid-forties, who also has no history of breast cancer in his family. When he would attend routine GP appointments to check how he was doing on the treatment, he found he caught the attention of student doctors, who would come into his appointments often. “You wouldn’t believe the amount of these doctors, five years in training, that didn’t have a clue what it was, they didn’t realise it was breast cancer, Gordon said. Gordon felt like a ‘guinea pig’ at times, as he was one of the first men to go on the hormone therapy. His we argues that it caused him to have mood swings at certain times of the month, similarly to PMT - premenstrual syndrome - when he first started out. And after seven years, he was able to come off it, though Gordon found this ‘frightening’. “It was a crutch in a way, so it was quite scary coming off it,” he said. “I thought that was going to protect me. It was down to my body then, no more medicine, which was rather frightening.” Whilst Gordon came off medication for the cancer, he was still on antidepressants as he battled with the aftershock of what had happened to him. Ever since the trauma, he’s regularly checked his remaining breast and around his scar, and encourages other men to do the same. Looking back, Gordon believes he’s lucky to be alive. He added: “I was lucky because I did nothing about it and it was just a bit of luck with the asthma attack. “I can’t believe how daft I was and blasé that I didn’t do anything about it. If I was left to my own devices I would have died, no question. “I want to get the message over to many men as possible that you can get breast cancer and also for men going through it, it’s not necessarily a death sentence. “Any change at all, get to the doctors immediately, don’t mess around”.To find out more about Walk the Walk’s awareness campaign, go to www.walkthewalk.org mengetbreastcancertoo.Comment MORE ON HospitalsBreast cancerTherapyCancer" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. news uk-news ex-primark-employee-shares-what-"Primark: Ex-employee shares what its like working in high street shopByGraeme Murray:,  Oct Updated:,  Oct | commentsA former Primark worker has shared what itaposs like to work in the popular high street store. The woman, a TikTok user, shared her experience in a video where she told about customersapos behaviour and how they would leave the fitting rooms wearing new items theyaposd just picked up on the shop floor.The social media user @kdr from London explained how shoppers would abandon their old clothes and swap them for new ones in the changing rooms.They would hand their old outfit, including dirty underwear to the shop assistant. She rolls her eyes in the TikTok video and said: When people handed in their own clothes to the fitting room and left wearing new ones from Primark when I worked there. She adds that there is a bonus point when it was their underwear. Her confessions prompted other Primark employees to recall their gross experiences while working for the budget clothes chain. One wrote I found a used sanitary towel stuck to the mirror when I checked the fitting rooms. Another posted an emoji of a man vacuuming which read: Me when I worked in Primark and a toddler p***** on the floor three minutes before the end of my sht. A third response claimed customers had disgusting behaviour: Someone pooped in a bag on my sht and left it there. One admitted she had handed their old clothes back to the shop assistant before walking out with her new clothes.  They said: -year-old me thought I was slick wearing old black jeans in and new black jeans out. But Georgia Ponton, , from Kettering, revealed how to benefit from free hanger and seasonal items in her TikTok post. In her response, she says: aposIf you go up to someone that is working on the till and say aposCan I have a bag of hangers apos then they will give it to you, she said. So stop buying hangers because you can get them for free. She suggested the best products were positioned at the back of the rails especially during changing seasons.  She said: aposCheck the back of all the rails. If the season was about to change, then we would put anything that needed to be sold right at the front and anything new at the back because we needed to prioritise the old stuff. Poleighh Soper, a former worker said when a request for Mr Brown comes over the tannoy, it is a call for security. She said: Say your security company that stands by the door and makes sure nobody is stealing… say their name is like aposBrown Security Servicesapos, thataposs who theyaposre calling. So, when they say aposCan Mr Brown please come to the customer service checkoutapos, theyaposre actually calling for security – they just donapost want the customers to know that. Staff would have to carry out theft checks at the tills according to the former worker.The Mirroraposs newsletter brings you the latest news, exciting showbiz and TV stories, sport updates and essential political information.The newsletter is emailed out first thing every morning, at noon and every evening. Never miss a moment by signing up to our newsletter here.  Poleigh said: You know when you go to the till and youaposve got like a makeup bag or something, theyaposll always open it up and take out the tissue  Thataposs to check that youaposre not stealing,. So, we have to take the tissue out to check thereaposs nothing  in the bag, however, weaposre not actually allowed to accuse you of stealing. aposWe could open that bag and find  pieces of jewellery and three pairs of socks in there – [but] canapost accuse you of stealing it. title: family speechless after finding halloween
story: Family speechless after finding Halloween note from McDonalds in Just Eat orderDeborah Busby, from St Helens, said her family couldnt believe it when they found a hand-written note on a napkin in a McDonalds order wishing them a happy HalloweenDeborah Busby, from St Helens, said that her family were touched by the message from McDonalds Image: liverpoolechoByAaron CurranTim Hanlon:,  Oct | commentsA family has told how they were surprised by a thoughtful gesture from McDonaldaposs when a delivery came with a handwritten note from staff. Deborah Busby said she had ordered a takeaway for her children Angel, , and Xan, , who live in St Helens, Merseyside.The family ordered their food from the McDonaldapos in St Helens town centre and they ate the takeaway as normal, reported the Liverpool Echo.It was only the following day that they discovered the note. Deborah told the Echo: When the delivery came, my son got to the door and gave Angel hers and she took it up stairs with the napkins.  The next morning she spotted a note on a napkin saying aposHappy Halloween love McDonaldaposs Casey, Mal, Hannahapos and showed her brother which made them both smile. She then showed my husband Geoff. At first he thought Angel was playing a joke on us but I could tell it wasnapost her hand writing. Deborah said that she then posted the message online as she wanted to show her appreciation for what the McDonaldaposs staff had done.I thought it was a lovely gesture and considerate thing that the young ladies had done. Such a personal touch, I then took to Facebook on the People of St Helens group to put up a post about it, she said.Deborah says her daughter appreciated the gesture that much, she has now put the note and drawing away to keep it safe. Deborah added: Itaposs the simple things that count and make a big impact. The post received a big response on Facebook, with many people applauding the McDonaldaposs workers for their gesture. One person commented: That is so sweet.... the Parents can be proud of their children. news uk-news first-time-buyer-saves-thousands-"First-time buyer adds thousands to property value with home renovationByKatie DollardEstel Farell-Roig:,  Oct Updated:,  Oct | commentsA first-time buyer saved thousands of pounds transforming a Victorian house by doing most of the work himself - and added £, to its value. Following his dadaposs footsteps, Edward Kercher bought the terraced house in January this year to take on a project.The -year-old said his dad renovates properties full time, which gave him the confidence to buy a run-down property and then bring it back to le.The architectural technologist said he has saved tens of thousands by doing as much work as he could himself but, with a full-time job, it has him taken ten months. Edward, from Southampton, has been working in the house after work and at weekends, having spent just over £, so far on the transformation.  He added: I work on my house renovation project after work and at the weekends. “Basically any free moment I get out of work I try to use as time to work on my house. Iaposve saved in the region of tens of thousands. I have lost out in terms of time as it has taken me a lot longer but I have saved a vast amount of money.Have you got a story that you think we should feature  Email us at webnews@mirror After moving, he ripped up the flooring and started stripping the walls. He also slowly stripped the paint of the original staircase to restore it.The first-time buyer ordered a kitchen from Howdenaposs for just over £,, including all the appliances, and then installed it himself.In the bathroom, he bought and installed the bathroom suite and added modern metro tiles, for a total of £. Edward decided to go for classic Herringbone flooring for the entire ground floor, costing £.  Upstairs, he sanded the original floorboards and spend £ on hiring equipment. Recognising the history of the house, Edward wanted to keep some original features in the modern design and, luckily, he was able to refresh the original doors, staircase and fireplaces. He said: “I think it is much better to try and do restoration rather than strip out and introduce new features. “I think the contrast between old and new works well.”  However, Edward did have to get some professional help after plastering one bedroom upstairs as, realising how time-consuming it would be to do the whole house, he hired a plasterer to tackle the ground floor and all the artex ceilings. He also hired a plumber, who moved his boiler into the loft. In total, he has spent just over £, so far on the transformation.  Now all that is left to finish are some smaller jobs to add the final touches and fill the house with furniture. When I was younger he [his dad] was always remodelling the homes that we lived in, he continued. I think that is one of the main reasons I have always been interested in doing something myself the same way. It gave me the confidence to buy a run-down property and know that I would be able to do all of the work myself to bring it back to le.”  Once heaposs finished everything, Edward plans to have the house surveyed and will decide whether to sell it and start a new project or live in it for a while. Although he doesnapost want to share how much he paid for the house originally, he believes all the work he has done has already helped it go up in value.Full Kitchen cost including appliances: £ Full Bathroom fixtures fitting and tiles: £ Herringbone flooring for the entire ground floor: £ Sanding equipment hire for first floor rooms: £ Rooflight in Kitchen: £ Tradesman Plastering the ground floor and all the artex ceilings: £ Plumber moving my boiler into the loft: £ Front door: £ Furniture so far sofa, two double beds and mattresses etc: £ Miscellaneous items : £ Total £, Edward believes that, since he bought the house, it has gone up in value by up to £,. He said: I have kept a close eye on house prices on my road and with the recent capital growth of property and my recent refurbishment I believe, within the nine months I have had the place, I have added around £,. For those looking to start their own home renovation, Edward added: “Itaposs so easy to fall into the trap of feeling overwhelmed and underskilled when it comes to DIY and property in general. You just need to take a risk sometimes and you always end up figuring things out. I went into this with zero knowledge and experience and now I have people asking me every day how I am so competent in DIY  renovation,you believe you will enjoy DIY and property, go for it, I promise you wonapost regret it. title: its both exciting soothing wild
story: It’s both exciting and soothing - the wild new hobby one woman swears byAs KFC launches its limited edition Zinger Popcorn Bucket, we celebrate the thrill of trying something newWould you try lake swimming AdvertorialByEimear OHagan:,  Oct Updated:,  Oct If we’ve learnt anything over the past year and a half, it’s that you never know what’s around the corner, so itaposs important to seize opportunities, push ourselves out of our comfort zone and live for the moment. KFC is doing just that by encouraging people to spice things up to mark the launch of its tasty new Zinger Popcorn Bucket - available for a limited time only. So to join in the fun, weaposre championing people who have challenged themselves to try new things, including Jenny Holden who has ed head first into wild swimming. The forty-seven-year-old mum of ten-year-old twins from Lichfield, Staffordshire, explains that she was in search of a new challenge, and one that would bring some excitement to her le.  ‘With my children a bit older, and less dependent on me, I found myself with a little bit more time for myself, and I wanted to use it doing something fun,’ says Jenny who runs her own PR company Chorus Communications. ‘Especially post lockdowns, with so much time spent at home, being sedentary and growing bored of my normal activities, I was craving a new hobby, and one that would really exhilarate me.’ A friend suggested Jenny try wild swimming at a quarry near her home and Jenny decided to give it a go, albeit with some nerves. ‘I’m a keen swimmer but the idea of swimming in that sort of environment was completely new to me. Also, wouldn’t it be freezing  I was intrigued enough to give it a go though, and took my first dip in August with one of my sons. ‘Plunging into the water, my first thought was – wow it’s cold! But actually, once you become acclimatised to the water temperature it feels wonderful. That first swim was really memorable, I came out of the water feeling revived and invigorated, and I knew I was a convert.’ Jenny persuaded three friends to form a wild swim gang with her and since August they have met weekly for a dip. ‘I don’t wear a wetsuit, it’s too much faff getting in and out of one, just a swimsuit and now I look forward to my swim all week. ‘Front crawling through open water, surrounded by the sounds and sights nature, it’s so amazing and it washes away the stresses of the week. It’s nothing like swimming in a pool, it’s both exciting and soothing, brilliant for body and mind. ‘It’s definitely going to get a bit nippier as we go into winter but I’m ready for the challenge!’ So in the spirit of taking the plunge and trying something new, e into a Zinger Popcorn Bucket soon - it is only around for a limited period, available until November .Download the app, head in store or order online. title: it took hour check 299
story: It took me an hour to check into £ room with no window at one of UKs worst hotelsThe reviewer arrived at pm at the Manchester Britannia and her heart sank when she saw a queue already forming outside of the grand double doors for check-inDianne Bourne was not impressed with her visit to Manchester Britannia Hotel Image: MEN MediaByDianne BourneGraeme Murray:,  Oct | commentsBudget hotel chain Britannia has attracted a rather unfortunate reputation in recent years having been repeatedly dubbed the UKaposs worst.In  Britannia was named the countryaposs worst chain by Which  for the eighth year running in a survey of , guests.It came last out of  major chains, with a score of just  out of , and there are hundreds of negative Tripadvisor that would likely agree with that ranking.Guests at some of the firmaposs  hotels have cited poor conditions, issues with rooms and y check in times among their many complaints online. The Manchester Evening News sent feature writer Dianne Bourneaposs visit to Manchester Britannia Hotel, to give her personal verdict on whether Britannia rules or not.Hereaposs what she had to stay about her stay:  Iaposm not quite sure where to start with my visit to Manchesteraposs Britannia Hotel. With the ONE HOUR queue to check in  With the bedroom without a window, stuffy and sweltering with an ageing air con that I couldnapost get to work  Or perhaps with the eye-watering £ price for it all  Not forgetting, of course, the people who kindly woke me at .am by screaming in the hotel corridors at the injustice of it all  So, anyway, when I got my booking information through for the Britannia I was surprised to see that check-in was from pm - which seemed a little late - but I figured that would still give me time to get ready ahead of the event I was attending at pm. I arrived at bang on pm at the Britannia, and my heart sank when I saw a queue already forming outside of the grand double doors for check-in. Waiting around does allow you to appreciate the grandeur of this th century building - the sweeping staircase and huge chandelier on entrance really are impressive, while Graeco-Roman style statues dot the alcoves and windows around the lobby.  However I became sick of the sight of the Roman Gods after staring at them for a FULL HOUR while waiting to get to the front of the queue. I got chatting to some nice people next to me in the queue - when I overheard them talking about how much they had paid for their room. And then they all got to have a good laugh when I told them how much I was paying. Because it turns out I was being well and truly ripped off with the £ charge - the two women from Scotland revealed theyaposd booked their double roomfor £ just three days before their stay .  A couple originally from South America revealed they were paying £ for their double. To say I felt ripped off at this stage would be an understatement. When I told them all my room was £ with NO WINDOW I honestly think they thought I was joking. Ah, you will be in the penthouse for that price, they said. No no, itaposs a room with no window, I tried to explain, but still they laughed. Finally, finally when I got to the check-in desk, there was no apology or explanation for the delay, just the request for my name.  Does it always take this long  I asked. And he reckoned it was just because it was a busy Saturday night in Manchester. Although when I later looked on TripAdvisor, I can see there have been numerous complaints about the hour-long check-ins for weeks now. I felt annoyed that it gave me less than an hour to get myself showered and ready to get to my event. But I felt even more annoyed on behalf of some shirtless males I encountered in the corridors as I made my way to my room.  They were very apologetic about their state of undress and the contents of their luggage all over the floor, but explained to me they needed to get changed quickly as they were already late for an event and just couldnapost wait any longer in the ridiculous queue for check-in. Itaposs just not on to pay for a hotel room and then not even be able to get into it, is it  I arrived at my room, having noted that room numbers on the doors were in a font that might best be described as Prisoner Cell Block H. Once inside my ground floor bedroom, the first thing that struck me was the wave of heat. Yes, I knew there was no window when I booked, but I had foolishly thought this would be in some way compensated by a modern form of air conditioning system. No such luck. An ancient looking grid was high on the wall, with a silver switch control  that was not exactly screaming digital age at me. While a little blue light flickered on the temperature setting, no such light was emerging from the fan switch. I tried and tried but nothing happened. Naturally, my first thought was to ring reception, but, funnily enough, given the fact there was still a queue out of the door at check in, there was no answer. And there was no way in hell I was going back out to queue for another hour to speak to someone. Aside from the heat, the room itself was pretty basic with old-fashioned dark furniture, and plain magnolia walls punctuated by two dirty round marks above the bedhead. But the bedding all looked clean and the bed itself felt comfy.  The TV remote was wrapped in a film with a sanitised sticker on it, and coffee and teas were also wrapped in a bag next to the kettle and cups to keep them clean. Above the skirting board appeared to be the power mains switches with the warning sign Danger  volts above it, which I found a little unsettling. The bathroom also looked to be clean, although when I touched pretty much anything in the shower it fell off in my hands - the soap dispenser, the shower power control and temperature ring. I mean, I was able to put them straight back on again so they all still ed ok, but not exactly the Ritz levels of quality is it  I was getting so hot now in the room that I thought Iaposd best just get cleaned up and changed as quickly as I could to get out into some fresh air.  When I ed to the hotel after attending my event, there was at least a blessing that the temperature had dropped outside by a few degrees so the heat of the bedroom was not quite as unbearable - although my flannel pyjamas were certainly not required for the sleep. Well, I say sleep. I was rudely awakened just after am by loud banging and crashing in the corridor, and a chap who sounded rather upset, presumably, having finally managed to check in to his room. He was shouting: I f***ing paid £... for THIS . Which I might have had some sympathy for, had I not forked out £... for THIS.  I settled back to sleep, only to be woken again around an hour later at .am by what sounded like a crowd disturbance on the street outside - not having a window I was unable to check what exactly it was that was happening. All that said, the bed was comfy and after the noisy interruptions it was a comfortable sleep. Waking at am I headed off to reception to complain about the heat of the room and the air conditioning not working. The man at the front desk said immediately would you like a plug-in fan  which gave me the impression I was not the first person to make this complaint. No, itaposs not worth it now I said. But I made the point they might want their hotel technical team to take a look at it so the next person doesnapost have to suffer in there. Heading down to Jennyaposs Restaurant in the basement for my buffet breakfast was perhaps the highlight of my stay.  Fine dining it ainapost, but the good old-fashioned all-you-can-eat fry up buffet was plentulyou were after a cooked breakfast - and there was quite a pile of fresh fruit too. I mean, donapost get me wrong, the sausage was like a salty fat stick and the mushrooms looked like theyaposd long ceased their status as vegetable, but it gets major brownie points for hosting what for me is the holy grail of hotel breakfasts - limitless fried bread. However, I could not forgive the god-awful coffee which tasted unlike any hot liquid I think Iaposve ever drunk before. Perhaps I picked the wrong jug of badly-brewed stuff, but I was not going to go and try another. Mercully, there was no queuing for check out, as you just popped your room key in a box on your way out. And, seeing the lobby empty, you can appreciate what a grand old building this really is, and what poteI couldnapost help but notice the one thing definitely not in short supply at the Britannia was racks and racks stuffed with postcards of the grand old building, all around the reception, should you wish to send a reminder to a loved one of your stay.The Mirroraposs newsletter brings you the latest news, exciting showbiz and TV stories, sport updates and essential political information.The newsletter is emailed out first thing every morning, at noon and every evening. Never miss a moment by signing up to our newsletter here.  Wish you were here  Erm, not so much no. We have asked Britannia Hotels for comment about the pricing scale for rooms, and the issues raised at my stay with check-in and the air conditioning, but there was no reply at the time of publishing. My overall take away from this stay is just the sheer rip off of the pricing. The windowless room is not the worst hotel room Iaposve ever stayed in here in Manchester but itaposs the one I felt most ripped off in. If you get this style of room at a budget price, then it offers reasonable accommodationyou just need somewhere to bed down for a few hours and shower . But for the £ paid for my visit, Iaposd have been better off booking a taxi to get me home - heck I could probably have got a chauffeur-driven limo for that price. news uk-news kate-middleton-popped-sainsburys-buy-"Kate Middleton holds spiderByJenner NewtonRoyal Features Writer:,  Oct | commentsWith Halloween fast-approaching, parents across the country will be making sure their kids have the perfect costumes for the spooky day. And it seems that the Duchess of Cambridge is no dferent after she was previously spotted popping into her local Sainsburys to stock up on Halloween outfits for Prince George and Princess Charlotte. Kate was seen at the supermarket on the Hardwick Industrial Estate, Norfolk, in  and was overheard asking some of the children in the store what they were going to dress up as. George and Charlotte were with their mum and followed her around as she did her shopping.  She later used the self-service checkouts, where she purchased her Halloween goods. Mum-of-four Kathy Whittaker later spoke of her shock to see Kate browsing the supermarket clothes while a brawny six-foot bodyguard lingered close by. Kathy explained: Another shopper said that Kate was in the shop near the clothing and pointed where she was to me. I just couldnapost believe it.  Love the royals for the Mirroraposs daily newsletter to get all the latest news on the Queen, Charles, Kate, Wills, Meghan, Harry and the rest of The Firm. Click here to sign up. She was with Charlotte and George looking at Halloween outfits but her bodyguard was kind of watching people with phones and telling them no pictures. I managed to get the photo as she was at the self-service check out. You just donapost expect it to happen, you think Kate would shop in Waitrose or Harrods.  However, itaposs not the first time Kate has been spotted in a Sainsburyaposs. She was also seen browsing the clothing section of the supermarketaposs Kingaposs Lynn branch, which isnapost far from the familyaposs countryside home Anmer Hall, in . While in , she was spotted perusing the aisles of discount store The Range in King’s Lynn. Teacher Sarah Daniels told how she saw Kate with George and Charlotte in the arts and craft aisle before they moved on to the toy section, where George apparently showed interest in ‘dinosaur slime’. Mrs Daniels told the Daily Mail that at one point Charlotte sat on the floor and was told by her mother, dressed casually in jeans, low-heeled boots and a jacket: Get up, poppet. And when George asked about the slime, she claims she didn’t register a response from the prince’s mother. Maybe slime wasnapost within their budget  Comment MORE ON Prince GeorgePrincess CharlotteKate Middleton, Duchess of CambridgeRoyal Family" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get our daily royal round-up direct to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: mum 11 who never over
story: Mum-of- who never got over death of son, , in scaffolding fall dies after car crashPaula Tfin, , lost her son Adam in an accident  years and tragically she has now passed away, two days after a car she was in smashed into a wall while being chased by policePaula Tfin pictured three hours before the tragic crash Image: Newcastle ChronicleBySophie DoughtyEstel Farell-Roig:,  Oct Updated:,  Oct The mum of a seven year-old boy tragically killed in a scaffolding fall has died after a horror car crash. Paula Tfin passed away two days after a car she was a passenger in smashed into a garden wall while being pursued by police in Washington, Tyne and Wear.The -year-old died in hospital after the smash left her with catastrophic injuries too serious to survive, ChronicleLive reports. Driver Bradley Webb - who drove at over mph through residential streets before losing control - has pleaded guilty to causing death by dangerous driving and Paulaaposs daughter Amie has now revealed her devastation. The -year-old has said she is comforted by the thought her mum is now back with her beloved seven-year-old son Adam, who died after he plunged ft to the ground from scaffolding near his home in .  Amie said: She was so strong, she lived for her kids, but she never got over what happened to Adam. It just totally messed her whole le up. She always believed she would be with Adam one day and that does comfort me. Paula was a happy devoted mum before her world was ripped apart by Adamaposs death  years ago. His horric death came just weeks after Paulaaposs baby daughter Angel was stillborn, but the mum-of- battled through the unimaginable pain for the sake of her other children and remained the rock they all relied on. Back in , Paula told the Mirror : I feel like my heart has been ripped out.I have lost two children in a month and I donapost know how I am going to cope. Adamaposs final words were I love you, mum as he left home to play. He had been playing out with his big brother Dylon when he scaled the scaffolding, near his home in Roche Court. Dylon ran home to tell his mum that Adam had fallen and Paula raced to where her boy was. But there was nothing she could do to save her boy, and Adam died in her arms.  At the time, she said she could tell straight away that he was dead, adding: I picked him up in my arms and he felt limp. People were trying to resuscitate him but it wasnapost working. We waited  minutes for an ambulance but it felt like a letime. He came up just before the accident, gave me a big kiss and said, aposI love youapos. Iaposm so glad I got to hear that before he died.Paula told the Chronicle in  she had blamed herself for allowing Adam to go out that day, saying she was trapped in a world of what-s and that she had been haunted by guilt since her sonaposs death.However, after a construction firm was fined £, for safety blunders, which led to the youngster’s death, Paula said she could finally forgive herself and start to move on.  Lovell Partnerships Limited, which erected the scaffolding for a one-off repair but left it there for  days, admitted responsibility for blunders which led to the tragedy. It was prosecuted by the Health and Safety Executive and fined the sum for a breach of safety regulations. Despite being freed from the guilt that had plagued her, Paulaaposs grief cast a dark shadow over the rest of her le. Mum-of-four Amie said her mum slept with the t-shirt Adam had been wearing the day he died under her pillow every night. Paula had been at Amieaposs house, in Hetton-le-Hole, enjoying a few drinks in the hours before the crash in August. Despite living close by she accepted a lt home off Webb, who is the brother of Amieaposs partner Jimmy, Amie explained. But the Renault Megane they were in crashed into a garden wall on Dairy Lane in Houghton-le-Spring, at around .am the following morning.Have you got a story that you think we should feature  Email us at webnews@mirror The car was being pursued by officers from Durham Constabulary at the time. Paula and another female passenger were taken to the Royal Victoria Infirmaryin Newcastle. . Meanwhile Amie was mistakenly told that it was her brother, -year-old brother Nathan, who lived with Paula, who had been injured in a crash. Frantic with worry she rushed to their home to look for her mum. And when Amie saw her brother and notice her mumaposs bed had not been slept in she was hit by the devastating reality. I had goosebumps from my head to my toes, I was a mess, Amie explained. Then the police knocked on the door. They said we needed to get all the family members to the RVI.  Paula underwent three major operations as medics battled to save her. But her injuries were too severe and she passed away on August  surrounded by he family. Paula was cremated last month with Adamaposs T-shirt in her coffin and her children are still struggling to come to terms with their loss. Her eldest son Darren said the tragedy had come just as things were starting to look up for his mum, who was in a happy relationship with her new partner. My mam has always been my rock. I used to go and see her every day, the -year-old said. I think she was stuck in the past. I think she was stuck in that day that Adam passed. But she was never selfish. She would rather help someone  that help herself. But everything was on the up for her. She had her new boyfriend and you could tell she was happy. Itaposs just not fair. Amie now wears a locket every day with her mumaposs ashes in it. She was very well-known around here, she said. Everybody loved her. She never stood still. She was always on the go. She was all about her kids. She gave us a good childhood. The Christmas and birthday presents were always piled up. Webb, , of Queen Street, Hetton-le-Hole, has also pleaded guilty to causing serious injury by dangerous driving and driving without insurance and without a licence. He is remanded in custody and will be sentenced at Newcastle Crown Court in December. title: mum 23 watched boyfriend battered
story: Mum, , watched on as boyfriend battered her baby leaving him with multiple injuriesChantelle Welsh pleaded guilty to child neglect involving failing to get medical help for the victim - she has now been jailed after the baby was left with multiple injuriesChantelle Welsh has been jailed after being found guilty of child neglectByTom DuffyLynda Roughley:,  Oct A young mum who watched her violent boyfriend seriously injure her baby son has been jailed. Chantelle Welsh kept quiet about the appalling incident for several hours before taking the little boy to hospital but repeatedly lied about how he had been injured - which led to her own brothers falling under suspicion and being detained in custody.The tot’s horrying catalogue of injuries included complex skull fractures, multiple eye socket fractures as well as a broken right arm and left leg, reported the Liverpool Echo. Liverpool Crown Court heard that the -month-old had “a large boggy swelling” to his head which he needed emergency surgery to reduce. He was discharged from Alder Hey Hospital after ten days and has fortunately physically recovered but there are concerns he may suffer psychologically in the long term. Welsh, , also has an older son but both have since been taken off her. The court heard that the defendant, who is now pregnant by another man, is unlikely to ever get her sons back and social services are involved in her le.  Welsh, of St Domingo Vale, Anfield, had pleaded guilty to child neglect involving failing to get medical help for the victim. Jailing her for  months Judge Garrett Byrne said: “A doctor refers to the injuries as would be seen in a serious car crash. “It is impossible to determine the long term psychological effect this trauma will have on this child, all one can say is there is the potential for long term psychological harm.” He told Welsh, who was dressed completely in baby pink, that her limited cognitive ability reduced her culpability but said the aggravating factors were “the time you took to seek medical attention and the lies told to the professionals which resulted in innocent people being arrested and detained, namely your brothers. Judge Byrne said it was “a shocking case” and she had “told a pack of lies” and it was only three months later that she started telling the truth. He said he had consideredhe could suspend the sentence on Welsh, who has no previous convictions, “but simply it was so serious only immediate sentence of custody can be justied.” John Williams, prosecuting, said that on the afternoon of February  last year the boy was taken to hospital by Welsh and her then partner. The baby had signicant swelling to his right eye which was completely closed and when examined he was found to have multiple injuries.  He listed the fractures the child had suffered as well as a perforated right ear drum and bruising to his right flank and abdomen. “There was no reasonable explanation as to how he had suffered these extensive injuries. “Neither she nor her partner were able to provide any explanation for the injuries. The nature and location of the injuries was such that clinicians rapidly concluded they were non-accidental and were indicative of signicant abuse.” Mr Williams said that the medics also concluded that the injuries had been caused on the day he was presented at hospital. The police and social services were notied and Welsh was questioned in the early hours of the next morning at hospital. She said she was unable to understand how he had suffered such injuries and he had not complained. It was only when she gave him paracetamol as he was hot that she and her mum realised his arm was floppy and decided to take him to hospital. Her two brothers, who lived in the same house as Welsh, were arrested as potential perpetrators as was her partner, who had not stayed at the hospital. The brothers were “detained for a signicant period of time. “ She was not in a relationship with the father of either of her sons and had only recently formed a relationship with the boyfriend. He did not live with her but he had been there overnight February  last year.  When interviewed she denied that her partner or brothers were involved in causing the injuries. Mr Williams said that the brothers were entirely innocent but she had lied about the partner. In family court proceedings which ran alongside the criminal proceedings Welsh admitted that her partner had inflicted the injuries. In an impact statement the victim’s paternal grandmother said the telephone call telling her about his injuries was “the worst news in the family’s le.” She said that the child, who the court heard had gone through a period of self-harming, was “more loved than he could ever want to be” and described the bond he has with her, his grandfather and his dad as “amazing.” Martine Snowdon, defending, said, “Her criminality flows from what happened after the infliction of these injuries. Her culpability is failing to act appropriately since she witnessed it.” She took him to hospital after a delay of about three hours and there is no evidence of any exacerbation of his physical condition as a result of the delay.” Miss Snowdon said that she knew her partner “had some involvement in crime and believed it to be drugs. He recently had a domestic violence conviction but she says she had no awareness of that”. Her telephone messages to him showed her immaturity with her telling him she loved him but no response from him. She had no awareness of the domestic violence background at the time he was in the bedroom with her and the injuries occurred. Miss Snowdon said no one would have known what had gone on in the bedroomshe had not gone on to tell the truth. She said: “She made a terrible mistake and she is deeply remorseful. She is deeply regretful of what she did. “She has spent approaching two years coming to terms that she is not getting these children back, probably for ever, and certainly for the foreseeable future.” Most ReadFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterMORE ON Alder Hey hospitalCourt caseSocial servicesCrimeDomestic violence" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: mum who lost kidney after
story: Mum who lost kidney after dehydration from weight loss surgery has no regretsMum-of-four Taren Maywald has struggled with her weight but it dawned on her thatshe didnt lose weight, her daughters childhood would pass her by just as it had with her other childrenTaren Maywald with her baby daughter Alice Image: Taren Maywald   SWNSByDaniel SmithGraeme Murray:,  Oct | commentsA woman who lost her kidney due to the side effects of le-saving weight loss surgery says she regrets nothing. Taren Maywald, , began putting on weight after childbirth when she had three children in the space of two years. Her eldest daughter, Pryscilla, , was born in , followed by her twin boys, Parker and Preston, , in , which meant she had little time to sht her baby weight.But the mum-of-four has struggled with her weight ever since, and over the past decade continued to pile on the pounds, with an unhealthy diet and worrying lack of exercise, HullLive reports.In  her youngest was born, and it dawned on Taren thatshe didnapost lose weight, her daughteraposs childhood would pass her by just as it had with her other children.  Weighing  pounds, she decided her best chance at losing weight was to travel to Mexico to undergo le-saving gastric sleeve surgery. In August , she went under the kne with the risk of never waking up from surgery, and came out the other side having lost % of her stomach.Taren, originally from Tarboro, North Carolina, said : I was told the surgery was a huge risk by the doctors but I didnapost care. I wanted to give myself the best opportunity of losing weight, and the surgery was a tool which allowed me to do that The procedure literally shrinks your stomach and restricts what you can physically eat. It stopped me binging and forced me to eat like a normal person, and straight away the results started to show. When Alice was born it drove me to change my le, as I was faced with missing her childhood because of my weight. I already missed so much of my other three childrenaposs lives and I was determined not to let it happen again. For a month after, Tarenaposs surgery seemed to have been a raging success, as she was steadily losing weight with every day that passed. However, at the end of September the stay-at-home mum started to suffer severe abdominal pain and gut-wrenching cramps. When Taren went to the hospital, she was told that sheaposd developed kidney stones as a result of dehydration caused by the weight loss surgery. After being admitted to the urologist, she underwent surgery on her left kidney to remove all the stones - but things didnapost go to plan and several exploded inside of her. The shrapnel from the stones buried itself in her kidney causing dozens of cists to develop - which in the end proved an inoperable condition.The Mirroraposs newsletter brings you the latest news, exciting showbiz and TV stories, sport updates and essential political information.The newsletter is emailed out first thing every morning, at noon and every evening. Never miss a moment by signing up to our newsletter here.  Six surgeries and almost a year later, her kidney had completely obliterated and she was forced to have it removed. Throughout the entire ordeal, despite living in excruciating pain, Taren was determined to build on the progress sheaposd made after her surgery. She went to the gym three times a week in-between hospital appointments and maintained her strict reformed diet. The results continued to show, and Taren now weighs a much healthier  pounds after shredding a whopping  and a half stone. Itaposs been the toughest year of my le without doubt but I donapost regret a single thing, she said. Going through this has made me a stronger person both physically and mentally, but most importantly it has enabled me to be a proper mom to Alice. news uk-news nearly--spikings-across-uk-"Bristol student opens up on suspected spiking at nightclubByRyan MerrieldReporter:,  Oct  said there have been  confirmed reports of drink spiking in September and October across ious parts of England, Scotland, Wales, and Northern Ireland" data-content-image"https:i-prod.mirror incoming article.ece ALTERNATES s _imagejpeg.jpg" data-tracking"facebook|share|top" said there have been  confirmed reports of drink spiking in September and October across ious parts of England, Scotland, Wales, and Northern Ireland" data-content-image"https:i-prod.mirror incoming article.ece ALTERNATES s _imagejpeg.jpg" data-tracking"twitter|share|top" said there have been  confirmed reports of drink spiking in September and October across ious parts of England, Scotland, Wales, and Northern Ireland" data-content-image"https:i-prod.mirror incoming article.ece ALTERNATES s _imagejpeg.jpg" data-tracking"whatsapp|share|top"Almost  drink spiking incidents have been reported to police forces across the UK over the past two months - as women share their horror stories. The National Police Chiefsapos Councilsaid there have been  confirmed reports of drink spiking in September and October across ious parts of England, Scotland, Wales, and Northern Ireland, plus  reports of some form of injection. On Friday afternoon, the NPCC said there were around  confirmed reports of drink spiking, but this figure was revised after more data was received. It said the number included both men and women, although the majority of cases featured young women. Alleged offences have taken place at licensed premises and private parties.Have you been a spiking victim  Tell us your story at webnews@mirror The  figure is based on data received from  police forces, and the NPCC said it is still to receive data from five forces which it expects over the weekend. The NPCC said  of the  reports of drink spiking were made to the politan Police. The NPCC lead for drugs, Deputy Chief Constable Jason Harwin, said: Clearly these reports are very concerning. We are working at pace with forces, law enforcement agencies such as the NCA and other partners including the Home Office and universities to understand the scale of offending, establish any links between the allegations and ultimately bring any identied offenders to justice. Two men have been arrested on suspicion of conspiring to administer poison in connection with a spate of reported drink-spiking incidents involving needles in Nottingham. Nottinghamshire Police said the men, aged  and , were arrested after receiving information from a member of the public on Wednesday, following a general appeal for help from a senior officer. The force said both had been arrested on suspicion of conspiracy to administer poison with intent to injure, annoy or aggrieve, and placed in police custody. The arrests are not being linked to any specic allegation of spiking by a needle, or contamination of a drink. Both men have since been released under investigation, the force said in an update. Nottinghamshire Police said it will deploy extra officers to ensure people can enjoy a safe night out. Miranda AriehMiranda Arieh, , thought she was going to die when her drink was spiked at a nightclub in Leeds.The mum-of-one had gone into the smoking area, only to be told by a bouncer to leave her drink on a ledge while she was outside. When she ed she took her drink back and drank about two-thirds before realising something was wrong, before dropping to the ground. “I just remember being so cold, and being so scared, and my head just collapsed between my knees, she told the Mirror. I had accepted I was going to die there. Miranda said she was discouraged from speaking to police, and believes victims need avenues to go where they feel safe. Katie Brady Katie Brady blacked out after being spiked while dancing at a nightclub in Newcastle.The mum, , from Gateshead, kept placing her drink on a podium but can remember nothing after the incident.She told Chronicle Live : I was told afterward that I had gone to the toilets and the door staff had to carry me out and give me water.[They said that] my eyes had rolled back into my head and that later on, I had just walked away from the bar. She was able to contact a taxi driver she knows and was taken home but fell backwards while being sick in her bathroom. Ilana El-baz University student Ilana El-baz was filmed lying completely paralysed on a staircase after her drink was spiked while on a night out in Bristol.Shocking images show the -year-old in a dficult state after she ed home and struggled to get up a flight of stairs while her eyes rolled and her head slumped on to the bannister. She says that she was spiked and has called on clubs to do more to protect revellers, including using lids on drinks, like with takeaway coffees, to protect clubbers.In an interview with the BBC, with whom she shared the footage, she said: Looking back on it, this guy spiked me and the moment I told him aposoh, Iaposm with my boyfriendapos he asked meI wanted to dance with him, and the moment I was like aposIaposm with my boyfriendapos he left me completely.And like an hour later I went back home and it hit and I was completely paralysed. Zara OwenTeenager Zara Owen was spiked with an injection and has shared her horrendous experience of waking up confused with no memory of the night out.Last Monday, the University of Nottingham student, , from Surrey, was out at a club with friends but has no memory after getting a drink at the bar. Speaking to the Mirror, Zara said: When it hit me I had been spiked, I was so shocked to realise this had happened to me as I take the safety measures given very seriously. I cover my glasses and I cover my bottles to make sure nothing goes in, but to realise I had been injected is terrying. After speaking to her friends, they informed her that she had been acting out of character, not making any sense and wandering off alone and after finding her outside pals got her in a taxi home. The next morning, she was shocked to find a pin-prick after examining her leg properly - but is still waiting to see her GP after being left to wait eight hours in AE before giving up and going home.Most ReadFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterMORE ON West Yorkshire PoliceNottinghamshire PoliceHome Officepolitan PoliceCCTVHospitalsCCTV footageCrimeAlcohol" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. news uk-news new-covid-epicentre-emerges-cases-"Coronavirus in numbers: UK reports , new casesByIan JonesDave BurkeSenior reporter:,  Oct Updated:,  Oct | commentsWorrying figures show the South West of England and parts of Wales have seen an explosion of Covid cases in a week - with some areas recording nearly  times as many cases. Cheltenham, Stroud, Tewkesbury and Swindon have emerged as Englandaposs worst hotspots, while Blaenau Gwent has the highest infection rate in the UK. It comes as pressure mounts on the government to act following a rise in cases and deaths which has seen a large gap open between the UK and its nearest neighbours. Latest Public Health England data shows  per cent of local authority areas have seen a week-on-week rise in new Covid cases. The South West has emerged as Englandaposs Covid epicentre, with Cheltenham recording , cases in seven days, up from . Nearby Stroud saw new infections rise from  to , in a week, while Tewkesbury had ,, up from . Scroll down to find out what the infection rate is in your area Blaenau Gwent in Wales continues to have the highest rate in the UK, with  new cases in the seven days to October  - the equivalent of ,. per , people. This is up sharply from . in the seven days to October . Cheltenham in Gloucestershire has the second highest rate, up from . to ,., with , new cases. Stroud in Gloucestershire has the third highest rate, up from . to ,., with , new cases. Armagh City, Banbridge  Craigavon has the highest rate in Northern Irelandand Clackmannanshire has the highest rate in Scotland . The five UK areas with the biggest week-on-week rises are:CheltenhamStroudTewkesburyBlaenau GwentSwindon Today Professor Peter Openshaw, a member of the New and Emerging Respiratory Virus Threats Advisory Group , said case numbers and death rates are currently unacceptable. He said measures such as working from home and mask wearing are so important as part of efforts to control the spread of Covid. The expertaposs warning comes after the Prime Minister resisted calls from health leaders for tighter restrictions despite the rising levels of infections. Health Secretary Sajid Javid said this week that new cases could reach , a day but Downing Street insisted there was still spare capacity in the NHS and that Plan B would only be activatedit came under signicant pressure.Plan B includes working-from-home guidance and the mandatory use of face masks. Speaking in a personal capacity, Prof Openshaw, of Imperial College London, told BBC Breakfast: Iaposm very fearful that weaposre going to have another lockdown Christmaswe donapost act soon. We know that with public health measures the time to act is immediately. Thereaposs no point in delaying. If you do delay then you need to take even more stringent actions later. The immediacy of response is absolutely vitalyouaposre going to get things under control. We all really, really want a wonderful family Christmas where we can all get back together. If thataposs what we want, we need to get these measures in place now in order to get transmission rates right down so that we can actually get together and see one another over Christmas.
