news uk-news rare-moment-kate-middleton-lost-"Kate Middleton arrives at the Forward Trust campaign eventByJessica TaylorReal le features writer:,  Oct Updated:,  Oct | commentsThe Duchess of Cambridge took to le as a royal like a duck to water when she married Prince William in . Having been with the Duke since university, Kate had become accustomed to the conventions and around being a Royal, including a key rule the family lives by - never complain, never explain. The idea is that members of The Firm keep their personal matters quiet and put on a happy face in public, even when times are tough. And Kate has been no exception since joining, flashing her trademark stunning smile while carrying out royal duties in public and winning the hearts of the nation in the process. However, over the years, there have been rare flashes of more candid moments from The Duchess of Cambridge. In , while she was five months pregnant with Princess Charlotte, Kate travelled to New York with Wills, where she visited a childrenaposs centre to help the wrap Christmas presents. During the visit, she stopped wrapping for a moment to chat to some of the volunteers about their work - but was given a telling-off. Kate was told to keep wrapping, at which point she showed a cheeky, light-hearted glimpse of what she was really thinking. Going back to wrapping and doing what she was told, Kate rolled her eyes. But she diligently carried out the work as asked and continued wrapping the presents. As she finished her visit to the centre, Kate is said to have thoroughly enjoyed her day - despite the funny reaction she expressed earlier. Sheaposs not the only royal to have lost her cool in the past, with a few funny incidents showing members of the royal family showing their true feelings. Just last week, The Queen expressed her frustration at world leaders who havenapost fully committed to attending the COP summit in Glasgow in November. Her Majesty said it was irritating to see some leaders appearing to not take their responsibility seriously when it comes to reversing the effects of climate change. And itaposs not just the adults who let their true feelings slip in public - with the next generation of royals expressing their anger too. While visiting Hamburg with her parents in , Princess Charlotte, then two, had a classic toddler meltdown on the tarmac at the airport. As William took a book from Charlotte that her brother had been given as a gt, she stamped her feet and got on the floor, just like any other tot in a bad mood. Luckily, mum Kate was on hand to scoop up her daughter before her antics turned into a full-blown tantrum. title: rare syndrome added possible side
story: Rare syndrome added to possible side effects of AstraZeneca vaccine by UK drug regulatorGuillain-Barre syndrome has been added to the list of possible side effects to having the AstraZaneca syndrome although it very rare and affects that immune systemA new syndrome has been added to the list of side effects from the AstraZeneca jab Image: Derby ByTim Hanlon:,  Oct | commentsA rare syndrome has been added to the list of possible side effects from the AstraZaneca vaccine by a UK health regulator. Guillain-Barre syndrome is a condition that has been noted in some people that have had the AstraZaneca jab, although experts insist the benefits of the Covid vaccine outweigh any possible side effects, The Medicines and Healthcare products Regulatory Agencyhas added Guillain-Barre syndrome as a possible side effect of the vaccine. The disorder affects the nerves mainly in the feet, hands and limbs, states the NHS. Numbness, pain or weakness can all be felt in patients with the condition which affects the immune system. For most people they will be treated and have a complete recovery but on rare occasions it can to lead to long term illness and may even be le-threatening.  Guillain-Barre syndrome had already been added to the side effects to the vaccine last month by the European Medicines Agency. Put in context, as of July  there had been  cases of the syndrome from million AstraZeneca doses given. Prof Tim Spector, an epidemiologist at King’s College London, has said that the most common side effect of the AstraZeneca jab is a headache and then comes tiredness. He is a lead researcher on the ZOE Covid study that examines symptoms of Covid and side effects of vaccines. Prof Spector used data from app users to compile his list of common side effects.  He tweeted that one in five people statistically feel unwell after having a vaccine dose with younger people more so which is believed to be because their immune system is stronger. Chills and joint pain were also typical side effects that were found after taking the AstraZeneca, the Pfizer or the Moderna jabs. For the Pfizer and Moderna jabs the most common side effect, according to Prof Spector, was tiredness followed by a headache. title: shoppers baffled tesco sainsburys hide
story: Shoppers baffled as Tesco and Sainsburys hide empty shelves with cardboard foodOne viral tweet shared by a Tesco customer showed a cardboard image of asparagus placed where the actual vegetable should be saying it "has the fake asparagus out this morning"Empty pasta shelves in a Sainsburys in Birmingham at the start of October Image: SWNSByDanya BazaraaSenior News ReporterKatie TimmsReporter:,  Oct Updated:,  Oct | commentsTesco and Sainsburyaposs stores appear to have covered their empty shelves with cardboard versions of the missing food in photos shared online. One viral tweet shared by a Tesco customer showed a cardboard image of asparagus placed where the actual vegetable should be. The tweet was captioned: Tesco have the fake asparagus out this morning. From afar, it could appear that the store had a full supply of the vegetable, but on approach, youaposd be disappointed. A Sainsburyaposs shopper replied to the tweet with a bizarre picture of her own. The woman shared a snap from inside a Sainsburyaposs store in Sherborne, saying that the supermarket was not even trying to make it look genuine.  The photograph, shared by Sharon Dale, showed empty pasta shelves at theLudbourne Road shop, with some of them filled with a cardboard insert.One person replied: Is dried pasta out of season too Speaking to Dorset Live, Sharon said she felt it drew attention to the lack of stock.She said: I have been reading a lot of comments about empty shelves and the cause .She said: I have been reading a lot of comments about empty shelves and the cause .  I thought it was a strange choice. I am already in Sainsbury’s so don’t need branded reminders. It draws attention to the lack of stockanything. A Sainsburyaposs spokesperson told The Mirror: Our colleagues and suppliers are working hard to make sure customers can find everything they need when they shop with us. Availability in some product categories may y but alternatives are available and stores continue to receive deliveries daily. The Mirror also contacted Tesco for comment.  It comes as a lack of lorry drivers and Brexit-related complications have caused queues at petrol stations and empty shelves in parts of the UK, while Felixstowe and other big ports around the world have suffered backlogs. As a result of the supply problems, the Department for Transportannounced plans to lt the limit on the number of deliveries foreign lorry drivers can make in the UK for up to six months. Currently, hauliers from the EU can only make up to two trips to drop off or pick up goods between locations in the UK within one week. Under the DfT proposal, there would be no restriction on the number of those journeys foreign lorry drivers can make over a two-week period before theyto their country of origin. Mr Shapps told Times Radio: “Christmas will go ahead. We’ll be able to see our friends and families. There will be food, there will be gts.“I do know that the entire world has a squeeze on its supply chain. That’s because we’re all coming out of this very long period of coronavirus, and the UK economy, perhaps particularly because we’ve got an expanding economy, the fastest-growing in the G, means that there are particular stresses and strains.“But we’re taking a whole range of measures, including one that I’m announcing today about the way that lorry drivers from abroad pick up and drop things off, the so-called cabotage rules. “And, under our changes, that will mean that they can, in an unlimited way by Christmas, pick up and drop off goods within this country within a -day period.” Comment MORE ON TescoSainsburysCoronavirusSupermarkets" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get our money-saving tips and top offers direct to your inbox with the Mirror Money newsletterInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: sick predator spiked womans drink
story: Sick predator spiked womans drink before sexually assaulting her and selling her phoneSean Howarth, , met the woman and her friends at a nightclub in Manchesters Gay Village and repeatedly complimented her despite her telling him she had a boyfriendPredator Sean Howarth preyed on the victim while she was on a night out Image: GMP   SWNSByAmy Walker:,  Oct A ‘depraved’ sex attacker spiked a woman’s drink on a night out, lured her back to his hotel room and sexually assaulted her - before stealing the contents of her bank account and selling her phone. Sean Howarth, , met the victim and her friends at a nightclub in Manchesteraposs Gay Village - repeatedly complimenting her despite her telling him she had a boyfriend. Whilst on the dancefloor he offered one of her friends some cocaine, but she declined and he then offered to buy the group a drink, including the victim, Minshull Street Crown Court heard.After taking the drink, the woman had little recollection of what happened next, the Manchester Evening News reports. Rachel Faux, prosecuting, said: “At am her friend noticed the victim behaving in a strange manner, she was hyper and dancing in an unusual fashion. “The victim then had some sort of panic attack and went outside to vomit, which was unusual for her.  “The friend went back inside the club to retrieve their coats so they could go home and gave the victim her phone.” As she went inside, Howarth headed outside directly for the woman. By the time her friend went to meet her, both Howarth and the victim were gone. Despite calling her she received no reply until the following morning when Howarth called her back on the victim’s phone stating that the victim was with him at his hotel in Rochdale and that she was safe, and sent her back home in a taxi. When the girl arrived back she was ‘shaking and crying’ with no memory of why she ended up in a hotel room, why she was with Howarth, or why she woke up with her trousers half way down her legs. She was also without her phone and bank cards which were kept in her phone case. The following day, police attended at the Royal Toby Hotel, where Howarth was staying, and found class A drugs. The day after he was released on bail and went to a Cash Generator where he sold the victim’s phone for £. He later used this and the stolen money to buy drugs. In a further interview he claimed she had pulled down her own trousers and he began to touch her until he realised she had fallen asleep. CCTV later showed Howarth and the victim walking towards Bloom Street and getting into a taxi. They stopped at a McDonalds where he bought some food but she could be seen ‘slumped’ against the rear window. Pulling up at the hotel, Howarth helped her out of the car as she was unsteady on her feet. He told the night porter that she was his sister, that she was drunk and askedit was OK to bring her inside, the court heard. They felt ‘intimidated’ by Howarth and allowed it, but later witnessed her trying to ‘break free’ from Howarth and heard her saying “no no”. CCTV from inside the hotel showed Howarth carrying the girl over his shoulder to his room, before dropping her to the floor in order for him to retrieve his food he left at reception. As part of the police investigation, Howarth’s phone was seized and examined in the note section was the victim’s passwords and security information and a recording he had taken of himself sexually assaulting her. Following tests, the presence of cocaine was discovered in the victim’s urine, though she had confirmed to officers she did not, and would not take cocaine. In an emotional victim personal statement, the woman said her whole le had changed and she was no longer the ‘bubbly, sociable’ person she once was. She said she no longer goes out socialising with friends for a drink, she has panic attacks when in crowded places and has completely changed jobs. She said she has lost friends as a result, lost her confidence and initially felt like she was to blame for what happened to her. “He left me with so many unanswered questions: Why did he pick on me  How did he think doing something like that was OK ” she said. “It’s clear from his actions that his only priority was himself.” Howarth was said to have two previous convictions for breaching non molestation orders against a former partner. Mitigating, Keith Harrison said: “In his basis of plea, he states he did not seek to stalk anybody. This offence was not planned in the sense of prior to arriving and seeing the complainant. “These offences are totally disrespectful and serious. “He behaved in a totally unacceptable manner. “There are very many good elements to this man - he fell from grace.” Sentencing, Judge John Potter told him: “This offending amounted to a series of planned quite deliberate events leading to the depraved act of sexual assault which you filmed on your mobile phone. “You then stole from your victim’s phone with all the money she had and you then took her mobile phone for yourself. “The selection of your victim by you and thereafter objectying her by dragging her into the hotel room to sexually abuse her and then stealing from her is clear evidence, in my judgement, of predatory sexual offending. “You have, in many respects, destroyed her hopes and expectations she was entitled to have in her young le.” Howarth, of Newsome Road, Huddersfield, was jailed for seven years and two months, made subject of the Sex Offender’s Register for le and also made the subject of a Sexual Harm Prevention Order indefinitely. He previously pleaded guilty to administering a substance with intent to commit a sexual offence, sexual assault, offering to supply a class A drug, theft and fraud. Detective Constable Russell Clarke, of Rochdale CID, said: The circumstances of this case are truly shocking and involved the premeditated violation of a young woman. Howarth gave her no consideration as he exploited her in order to satisfy his own sexual and financial greed. He added: Throughout the investigation, Howarth failed to take full responsibility for his predatory behaviour. He changed his story on a number of occasions, spinning a web of lies as he persisted in trying to distance himself from what he had done.Most ReadFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterMORE ON CCTVBanksCCTV footageCourt caseCrown courtCrimeCocaine" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: supermarkets like tesco moving checkout
story: Exclusive: Supermarkets like Tesco moving to checkout free shopping could cost m jobsAs Tesco and Amazon lead the way on stores that have no scanners or tills, it is feared almost a third of the industry’s . ­million-strong workforce face the axeStores are trying to solve a problem that doesnt exist say critics Image: PAByStephen Hayward:,  Oct | commentsA million jobs could be lost over the next decade as supermarkets move to checkout-free shopping. Tesco opened its first till-free store last week in High Holborn, Central London. Cameras track every item put in baskets at the GetGo store and payment is taken via a phone app as shoppers leave. Aldi is trialling the same system, while Morrisons is testing its own model. Amazon is opening five till-free shops in the capital this year. Clive Black, analyst at Shore Capital, says staff still need to stack shelves, help shoppers and stop shoplters. He said: “We’re in the foothills of this digital transformation.“The biggest vulnerability is head offices, where a lot of s will be automated.  “By  we’ll see a million fewer workers in retail.” Shop workers union Usdaw said: “Disputes over errors and customer confusion can be flashpoints for abuse of staff. “Retailers are chasing solutions to problems that don’t exist.” Tesco said its London shop would still employ  staff, which it says is in line with other comparable stores.Comment MORE ON MorrisonsAmazonTescoAppsSupermarketsSunday People" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get our money-saving tips and top offers direct to your inbox with the Mirror Money newsletterInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: terrified woman injected muscle relaxant
story: Exclusive: Terried woman injected with muscle relaxant on hen do as spiking cases soarRebecca Derbyshire,, believes she was injected on a night out in Liverpool and has warned people its not just students drink-spikers are targeting as country sees huge in incidentsPolice believe Rebecca was injected with muscle relaxants on a hen do in Liverpool Image: Rebecca DerbyshireByLaura Connor:,  Oct | commentsA woman spiked with a needle on a night out has told how her pal saved her from evil predators. Landscape designer Rebecca Derbyshire, , was injected with an unknown drug while on a hen do in Liverpool. Rebecca, from Stoke-on-Trent, Staffs, said: “I felt something sharp go into my shoulder. It was a really unusual sensation. “I turned around to my friend and said, ‘I think I’ve just been injected’. She looked at my arm and said there was a needle mark and we looked around trying to see who might have done it. “It doesn’t bear thinking about what could have happenedmy friend hadn’t been there.Get all the latest news sent to your inbox.for the free Mirror newsletter  “I think I was targeted when she had stepped away and I was on my own at the bar, making me more vulnerable. Most of my friends had already headed home but thankfully we stuck together.” Rebecca and her friend, who were drinking in the Rubber Soul bar in the city centre on September , went straight back to their hotel as she began to feel sick and drowsy. She said: “I was mainly a bit fuzzy, confused and quite shook up, feeling a bit nauseous and dizzy.” She later had a medical check-up, including HIV and hepatitis tests. Doctors told Rebecca that whoever injected her did not know what they were doing because they missed her blood stream. She said: “The doctors think it was probably muscle relaxants which could have temporarily paralysed me, but we will never really know until we find out who did it.” It was only this week after seeing other victims of needle spiking come forward that Rebecca reported her ordeal to police. Nationwide, cops have reported  needle spiking attacks in the past two months and  cases of drink spiking.  Nottinghamshire police have received  reports this month of people being spiked by something sharp. That includes three within just  hours this week. It coincides with an overall rise in reports of spiking using both needles and drinks this month. Rebecca said: “Afterwards I thought I was being paranoid and going mad, and I tried to put it to the back of my mind. “I think there was an assumption it was just students, but my story shows anyone considered to be an easy target can be attacked.” Two men in Nottingham and one in Lincoln were detained in connection with spiking attacks last weekend. An  and -yearold remain in custody in Nottingham on suspicion of conspiracy to administer poison. It is still unknown exactly what drug is being used to spike victims.  Jo Cox-Brown, founder of Night Time Economy, delivered anti drink spiking training on Friday to Nottingham venues. She said it is crucial to report a spiking to police as soon as possible because date-rape drugs like rohypnol and GHB leave the system within  hours. She said: “The earlier you report it, the more likely the perpetrators can be found immediately.” Home Secretary Priti Patel has ordered police to urgently investigate the rise of spiking. More than , people have signed a petition to make it a legal requirement for nightclubs to thoroughly search guests on entry. The Rubber Soul bar declined to comment.Most ReadDont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON Priti PatelEducationPoliceCrimeHen nightSunday People" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: woman who put weight finds
story: Woman who put on weight given devastating cancer diagnosis during pandemicExpecting hospital staff to tell her nothing was wrong Abby Younis, of Litherland, Merseyside, was shocked to hear that scans had revealed a cancerous mass in her stomachAbby Younis, who works as a financial crime consultant, had started to feel out of sorts in January  Image: Abby Younis   Liverpool EchoByLee Grimsditch:,  Oct Updated:,  Oct | commentsA woman who felt she needed a holiday and time off work after putting on weight and feeling breathless was given devastating news by doctors. Abby Younis, who works as a financial crime consultant, had started to feel aposout of sortsapos in January . Abby, who lives with her husband Brian in Litherland, Merseyside, thought she needed a break to get her back to her old, energetic self.She told the Liverpool Echo : I was working really hard and getting migraines and feeling tired.I just wanted to take some time off to get fit again as normally Iaposm a very energetic and into my fitness but I had put on some weight and couldnapost breathe properly. Taking time off, she caught up with family and friends and booked a once-in-a-letime holiday to Tanzania. However, after ing from holiday she still felt unwell and in constant need of having a wee. She said: I was breathless all the time. I had a lot of pains in my abdomen - at times they were quite paralysing, I couldnapost move. After dismissing it as something Iaposd eaten or time of the month I thought it was time to go to the doctors.  After a visit to her GP, it was suggested her problem may be bladder related and she was sent to the Royal Liverpool University Hospital for tests. Expecting hospital staff to tell her nothing was wrong, Abby was shocked to hear that scans had revealed a mass in her stomach. They didnapost knowthe mass was coming from her oies or bowel and so Abby was sent for further tests at the Liverpool Womenaposs Hospital and the Clatterbridge Centre. Initial results from a CT scan revealed that she had a pulmonary embolism - a blockage in one of the arteries in her lung which explained her breathlessness. Results from further blood test revealed more sinister news as Abby was told by doctors that they suspected the mass in her stomach was cancer. Abby said: It had got quite aggressive by that stage. They said my mass was too big to have a biopsy. The only way to knowit was cancer for sure was to undergo surgery. Following the shock news, doctors raced her appointment for surgery through as quickly as possible as wards were beginning to close due to the pandemic. Abby said: Before I left my home for the hospital, I left it in a way that I wouldnapost come back. Normally Iaposm such a positive person but because of where we were at the time. I thought Iaposve possibly got cancer, I know Iaposve got an embolism, and thereaposs Covid out there. I thoughtmy lungs or my cancer doesnapost get me, then Covid would. I couldnapost see past that moment in time. Three weeks after surgery to remove two masses in her stomach, Abbyaposs consultant called her into the hospital. She said: The consultant said they found something that we were expecting and something that they were not expecting. They had found two separate cancers growing at dferent rates. The more progressed one was oian cancer and that had spread across my bowels. Luckily they scraped off the cancer and didnapost have to remove part of my bowel. And separately I had endometrial cancer growing, which is cancer of the womb. Following Abbyaposs successful surgery to remove the tumours, she was offered chemotherapy which she declined unless they reappear again some time in the future. However, Abbyaposs surgery brought on whataposs known as a surgical menopause. She said: They tell you all the side effects before you have surgery and one of those is menopause - surgical menopause for people like me going through hormonal cancers. But you donapost know what that means, because Iaposve never heard anyone speak about it. Itaposs more of a crash bang wallop rather an easing in to the menopause. I had a lot of sleepless nights, I was in a lot of pain because of the surgery. I had terrible brain fog and hot flushes which were a complete nightmare. It was like somebody throwing a bucket of boiling hot water over me. Because Abbyaposs cancers were hormonal related she wasnapost allowed Hormone Replacement Therapyto help with her symptoms as it could cause another cancer. To help other women who are experiencing the menopause but canapost receive HRT, Abby is fundraising to buy Liverpool Womenaposs Hospital equipment to provide a new laser treatment that alleviates some of the symptoms of menopause. The treatment is currently only available privately and Abby is trying to raise as much money as she can to make the treatment available on the NHS. So far, she has had support from celebrities like Davina McCall, who sent Abby a personal video in support of her campaign. John Lewis are also hosting a fashion and beauty event in November to help raise money. Abby added: HRT is no good for people like me and thataposs why I want to fundraise for this laser. But the good thing is the awareness is getting out there and theyaposre talking about it now. news uk-news x-rays-show-stark-dference-"Boris Johnson: Nothing to suggest lockdown is on the cardsByTom Ambrose:,  Oct Updated:,  Oct | commentsX-rays have revealed the stark dference between the lungs of those who have had the Covid vaccine and those who have not. The scans show the shocking impact Covid has on peopleaposs internal organs with doctors saying unvaccinated people are the ones getting really sick. Dr Sam Durrani, the chief of staff at Deer Valley Medical Center, said: The only people that are really getting sick are people that are unvaccinated. [They] oftentimes require ventilation and oxygen, especially on some of these really profound X-rays that we are seeing. Vaccinated patients who are infected with Covid have more air flowing to their lungs, with the larger part of the lungs coloured in black on the scans, Dr Durrani explained. This means there is very little or no damage to the lungs. The image of a scan from an unvaccinated person shows that the lungs are very congested, limiting the oxygen flow throughout the entire body. Dr Durrani said: If you have a vaccinated patient that comes to the ER with a breakthrough infection, that maybe have some shortness of breath and we do a CT scan, they’re not nearly as bad as the unvaccinated patients. Even the breakthrough infections that end up getting pneumonia, their CT scans still were not as bad as the ones of unvaccinated patients. Vaccines have been successful in preventing severe illness and death in most people who catch Covid, but it will not work for some. Some double-jabbed people will still end up in hospital with Covid but with a much lower level of congested lungs compared to those without any vaccine protection. Data from the US Centers for Disease Control and Preventionshows that risk of dying from Covid is  times higher for unvaccinated adults than those who have been inoculated. In England, just one per cent of all Covid deaths are in those who have been fully vaccinated. The vaccine is working extremely well and is keeping the virus from progressing to pneumonia or infiltrating the lungs, Dr Durrani said. When you get a dose you can get a little sick, but eventually your body recognises it, it attacks it and you don’t get hospitalised, you don’t get put on a ventilator, it’s very profoundly effective. title: woman 26 left smelling like
story: Woman, , left smelling like old pennies after her skin gets hooked to creamLyndsie Wright, , used the creams during the transition from warmer to cooler months, as her skin would flare up, but never found her condition unmanageableLyndsie Wright in November  Image: Jam PressByRia Newman:,  Oct | comments A woman has shared how her body was left covered in an oozing rash after her skin became hooked to an eczema cream.Lyndsie Wright, , from Alabama, US, was diagnosed with mild eczema at the age of five, and was given steroid creams to treat it – which her doctor warned her parents could cause thinning of the skin. She used the creams during the transition from warmer to cooler months, as her skin would flare up, but never found her condition unmanageable. But, at , after two pregnancies which appeared to cause more flare ups in her skin, the eczema began appearing in new areas, including her upper lip and arms so she used the cream more frequently. She found that the treatment was becoming less effective, and researched online to find a reason. Then she read about topical steroid withdrawal– severe symptoms experienced by long-term users of steroid creams after they stop use. While other people had documented horric reactions, including red, cracked and itchy skin, Lyndsie didn’t believe she was suffering from it until she decided to quit using the creams in September  to test the theory. “All hell broke loose,” Lyndsie, who is mum to Angel, seven, Justice Jr, five, Aria, three, and Lennox, two, told Jam Press. “The first month after stopping, my face and eyes started swelling so badly. “My rashes started to spread even more, and towards the end of the month my skin was burning and itching so badly that I couldn’t even shower or soak in the tub – my skin couldn’t tolerate water at all. “It felt like acid was being thrown on my skin when I was taking a bath – the itch was intolerable. “By month two, about  per cent of my body was covered in this burning, and non-stop itching rash that continued to worsen. “Between December  and January , my body started to ooze liquid that smelt like old pennies. “I absolutely hated my appearance – I felt like I had lost myself. “During the oozing stage, my oldest daughter would pray at night that I wouldn’t have bad skin anymore so I could hug her without it hurting. “I couldn’t take care of my kids, let alone myself, and so I felt I had lost a part of me.” The oozing even caused the skin around her ears to crust over. It had stopped by February  but she was still fully covered in the “red, itchy and burning” rash. When she visited her dermatologist, Lyndsie claims she was told she would never heal without medical intervention. While Lyndsie was in severe discomfort, she decided to persevere without going back to the steroid creams, believing them to have caused the adverse reaction. Throughout her journey, her husband, Justice, reassured her she was beautul and took over the childcare while she recovered. Lyndsie said: “He made time to believe in me and keep me motivated and in a positive mind frame. He never let me sink into depression nor gave up on me – for that I will forever be grateful for him.” Between March and September , her skin finally started to slowly heal, and by January  the majority of her body had healed. Lyndsie said: “Seeing my skin now makes me feel like a butterfly. I went through hell to be able to transform myself – not just on the outside, but on the inside as well.” Despite all she has been through, Lyndsie doesn’t regret choosing to come off of the creams – not least because her knowledge of TSW has helped her make dferent medical decisions when it comes to her children. She said: “My youngest daughter was diagnosed with eczema following taking an antibiotic for an ear infection which resulted in a rash all over her body, when I was about six months into my journey. “SoI had not went through this I would have used steroid creams on her because that would have been all I knew. Instead I focused on her diet, I used all natural remedies to help her skin heal. “She’s now eczema free – which I also don’t believe she had eczema to begin with, I believe she had an allergic reaction to the medicine. “This journey transformed me to a more positive person all together. I will never take for granted the little things, like just being comfortable with a shirt against my skin.” Her skin is currently totally healed, and the only flare ups she has now are “tiny” and “normally hormonal”. Lyndsie added: “I am now able to live a normal, comfortable le. “Going through topical steroid withdrawal, I felt I was robbed from so many things – but I refuse to look at this experience negatively. “It’s been a blessing in disguise. I was never a huge positive thinker [before], but I’ve been able to stay positive the majority of this time. “The most meaningful thing to me is that my children got to see me overcome this and I hope when they are older it will be an example of inner strength. “Overcoming this has made me feel invincible, like I can take on anything the universe throws my way.” Comment MORE ON SteroidsMedicineEczema" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: fan theory suggests everyone kids
story: Fan theory suggests everyone on kids TV show Ed, Edd and Eddy is deadThe popular show, which debuted on Cartoon Network in , has been the subject of much speculationThe show first aired on Cartoon Network more than  years ago Image: Bauer-Grfin via GettyByEdward KayNiche Video Journalist:,  Oct Fan theories can give a television show le long beyond its runtime, with people loving to speculate on the intricate details of some of their favourite shows. But one show you might not have expected to hear a complex conspiracy theory about is popular kids programme Ed, Edd n Eddy, which ran from  to  on Cartoon Network. The show was a massive hit with children at the turn of the millennium, as shown by a longevity not matched by many programmes made for kids. But new leand a completely dferent perspective has been given to the show thanks to this popular fan theory found on Reddit. The post goes into a fair bit of detail when it comes to the show, with the overarching theme being that all of the children featured on the programme are actually dead. The theory states that everyone featured in the show has died and that the cul-de-sac in which the children live is actually meant to be purgatory. According to the post, each character represents a dead child from a period in American history, ranging from the early s right up to the year . Of the title characters, supposedly Eddy was a s con artist who tried to make a quick buck but died by drowning after running away from kids who he owed money to. Siblings Ed and Sarah are said to be typical s children, with Ed being something of a recluse, obsessed with monster movies and sci-fi and they apparently perished in a car crash. Finally, Edd was supposed to be the son of middle class s parents, who had no time for their son who was killed in a science experiment gone wrong, apparently leaving him scalped, hence the hat he never takes off in the show. The full theory goes into slightly more detail about some of the other supporting characters, as well as offering some evidence in the form of the children’s strange skin tones and oddly-coloured tongues.The original post can be found on Reddit here, so go and take a read for yourselfyou want to ruin some childhood memories.Most ReadDont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterMORE ON RedditCartoon NetworkCar crashesFrisk" data-immediate"data-immediate" to FREE email alerts with news to brighten your daySubscribeInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. news weird-news mum-shows-staggering-dference-between-"TikTok user shares size dference between jeans at the same shopByRosaleen FentonAudience Writer:,  Oct | commentsA woman has revealed the staggering dference between four pairs of jeans that she bought at the same store.While shoppers know that sizes y between stores, Megan Perkins Lukeaposs TikTok video shows how clothes bought from the same store can also y.She shared the video to remind people not to feel badtheir clothes donapost fit them, as she warned: This is why women hate their bodies. Taking to TikTok, the mom stacked four pairs of jeans that she had just purchased from Old Navy. Speaking as she showed the dference in sizing, she said: And this is why women hate their bodies.  Get the news you want straight to your inbox. for a Mirror newsletter hereFour pairs of jeans, dferent styles, all lined up. All button fly, all from the same company, all the samesize. But, as she showed off the dferent pairs of jeans, it became obvious that they were not the same fit. Perkins Luke pointed towards the pair of jeans at the bottom of the stack, saying: Huge on me. As she moved up the three other pairs, she continued: Fits perfectly. A little snug. Canapost even get over my hips. Along with the video, she added: Don’t judge your body by the number on the label.Viewers were shocked at the dference and many thanked her for highlighting the issue in her video, which racked up more than  million views. One woman wrote: I needed to see this. A second one commented: This is not why I hate my body. Itaposs why I hate shopping for jeans. And a third commented: Iaposm slowly learning to stop bothering with sizes and just buying what fits. Iaposm not cryingitaposs large when Iaposm usually a medium. Another added: I agree with this. I cry and get frustrated with myself. I cried on Christmas when the jeans my mum got me didnapost fit and they were all the same size. news weird-news mum-stitches-after-realising-frosted-"TikTok users husband hilariously tests privacy of frosted windowByRosaleen FentonAudience Writer:,  Oct | commentsIf thereaposs one room in our home you really want to be private, itaposs the bathroom. Whatever youaposre doing in there - in the shower, bath or on the toilet, itaposs not for public consumption. One mum was left rather red-faced after asking her husband to aposshower in front of the bathroom window while she stood outside, after becoming suspicious that the frosted window may not censor enough. And she was right - their neighbourhood was seeing a lot more than theyaposd bargained for.Mum Jill Santom shared a video of her husband fake showering on TikTok, where it left people in stitches. Get the news you want straight to your inbox. for a Mirror newsletter hereShe explained: I felt like people could see me even though itaposs frosted glass. So I asked my husband to pretend heaposs showering so I could see. The hilarious video, filmed outside her home, in Tennessee, at night left people in hysterics - as her husband took his role very seriously. The footage shows a clear silhouette of him standing by the window as he commits to his role and pretends to scrub himself.The mum posted another video, showing what people could see in the day -and it was even worse, as you could clearly see her daughter standing clothed by the window. One person joked: Put up a large image of Jesus. So that anyone who dares to look can feel judged. Another wrote: OMG I have the same window and on a golf course. Iaposm now horried! A third added: That window has got to go. One viewer quipped: Hope the neighbours will pay well for the show. And this is why windows in showers are NEVER a good idea, wrote another. title: my partner wont good parent
story: My partner wont let me be a good parent - she controls everything I doA man has opened up about feeling like he cant be a good parent, because his partner wont let him discipline their child and says he needs to earn the parent titleThe man doesnt feel like hes able to be a parent Image: Getty ImagesByEmma RosemurgeyAudience Writer:,  Oct | commentsWhether youaposre a step-parent, a grandparent, a foster parent or a biological parent, raising kids is hard. However, while itaposs normal for parents face challenges, one man has opened up about how he finds it completely impossible to be a good parent, because his girlfriend wonapost let him do so. The man and his partner got together  years ago but have never gotten married due to his girlfriendaposs commitment issues. Six years ago, his partner decided she wanted a baby, but instead of having a child together, the woman opted to get pregnant via a sperm donor so the child would legally be hersthey were ever to split up. While the child is biologically and legally hers alone, Iaposve been raising the child together since day one. We both work full time and split the expenses but I do the lionaposs share of chores,it matters, the man explained on Redditaposs Am I The A**hole forum. Problem is, as the child grows, she becomes increasingly protective. By protective, I mean she doesnapost let me use common parenting methods, like natural consequences and setting boundaries. Every thing I try to do, she undermines or undoes it.  He continued: This is NOT what we had agreed upon before having the child. We took parenting classes, read books and attended workshops. Now it seems she has thrown all that out the window. Our child can do whatever she wants, eat only jellybeans for breakfastso she fancies, stay up past midnightshe still wants to play. Of course that is not healthy. Most recently, the child - who is about to turn six - aposdoodledapos all over the manaposs laptop, and his girlfriend wouldnapost even let him sit her down to explain why it was wrong. In short, she doesnapost say no, doesnapost teach child right from wrong, and doesnapost let me do it. The kindergarten teachers have already complained a ton about behaviour issues and suggest that we have our child evaluated, which we did, he continued. The specialist gave us some insightful advice that my girlfriend chose to ignore because she believes her child is perfect, and she is actively preventing me from carrying out those advice, such as setting a schedule, limit sugary foods etc. For more of the news you care about, straight to your inbox, sign up for one of our daily newsletters here. The man says heaposs tried to sit his partner down to discuss the issue more times than he cares to count, but she doesnapost see an issue, and has even dismissed his ideas of family therapy. Instead, the girlfriend has told him heaposs the only one with a problem, which has been internalised by their child, who thinks heaposs the bad guy. I wanted to try harder because I really love the child evensheaposs not mine biologically, but today I overheard my girlfriend tell her that I aposstill need to earn the parent titleapos and I broke, the man continued. I pulled her aside and told her I can never be the childaposs parent because she wonapost let me. Now sheaposs mad, accusing me of trying to abandon our child and giving me the cold shoulder. The man then confessed he felt guilty because while the little girl wasnapost around to hear the argument, he fears she will pick up on it because sheaposs a smart kid. Iaposm so sorry but itaposs not going to get better, itaposs only going to get worse. Cut your losses and leave, one Reddit user commented. I know you love the kid like your own, but your partner is already alienating her from you and youaposre still right there. Leave while you still have youth and heart to start over. Another added: She doesn’t want to be a committed partner or a co-parent with you. She doesn’t want you to parent her child . Just leave and find someone who will actually let you into their le. Do you have a story to share  We want to hear all about it. news world-news british-afghans-beg-uk-save-"Brits trapped in Afghanistan plea for Boris to help themByGrace MacaskillNorthern feature writer:,  Oct  Holding their British passports, desperate men in Afghanistan appeal to Boris Johnson to save them from the Taliban.They risked their lives to make a film begging the UK to fly them home, after meeting in secret in Kabul. Over  British Afghans are believed to be stranded in the country following the abrupt withdrawal of Allied troops in August. Many were caught up in chaos at Kabul airport as people stampeded to catch the last flights out. Behind the camera is a Bradford dad-of-three who tonight told of families surviving on scraps of food in abandoned buildings. They hide as the Taliban go door to door hunting those with British links.  The -year-old businessman, whose children are aged seven to , said: “It’s starting to get cold. We have no cooking facilities so are living on cheese, bread and biscuits.” He said he and his we are forced to send the children out to buy food or risk being killed on sight.  He added: “We are utterly desperate now. Only a handful of people have been offered flights from the Government, but it is not offering to airlt our families. “I look into the eyes of my children, who ask every day when the Prime Minister will save them.” He regularly flew to Afghanistan for business and met his we there. He was in the process of bringing her to the UK when he became stranded.  In the heartbreaking film, he tells how many of those trapped, including engineers, medics and builders, were holding on to the dim hope of rescue. He said: “We met to record this message in the hope than someone out there will hear our voice and take action. It looks like the UK has... abandoned us.” The Foreign Office said: “We will continue to do all we can to secure safe passage to enable British nationals and eligible Afghans to leave the country.” Most ReadDont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterMORE ON Boris JohnsonTalibanForeign OfficePolitics" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get UK politics insight with our free daily email briefing straight to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: woman left swollen lips after
story: Woman left with swollen lips after centipede bites her mouth while she sleepsAs she was also suffering from shortness of breath, Nataly Galdino decided to get medical attention after the incident on October  when the centipede bit her on the mouthNataly Galdino, , from São Vicente, Brazil, had to go to hospital Image: Jam Press @natalyvgaldinoByLaura Abernethy:,  Oct Updated:,  Oct | commentsA woman ended up with huge swollen lips after a centipede bit her on the mouth while she slept. Nataly Galdino, , from São Vicente, Brazil, had to go to hospital and spent two days looking like she had had fillers because of the arthropod. I was sleeping and, in the middle of the night, I felt something prick my upper lip and I saw that it was stuck to my blanket and the claw in my mouth, but as it was dark all I did was pull, she said. I pulled and didnapost want to let go. I tried for five seconds, with unbearable pain and it wouldnapost come unstuck. I got out of bed, turned on the light, saw my cut mouth and the giant centipede on the deck. Although centipede venom can typically cause swelling and some pain it isnapost usually dangerous to humans, but Natalie was concerned because of the location of the bite around her mouth. As she was also suffering from shortness of breath, she decided to get medical attention after the bite on  October. She said: My mouth immediately started to swell and I ran to the hospital, there they medicated me with medicine for pain and allergy.  I ed home and it took two days to deflate. She said the experience was nerve-racking as she didnapost know much about centipedes, whether the venom was poisonous orshe would die.Now fully recovered, Natalie shared the story with her followers on her Instagram stories and warned them the creatures like humidity, so itaposs important to look out for them around your home.Comment MORE ON Angelina JolieHospitals" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. .dct-cta__image-wrap+.dct-cta__content@supports or.dct-cta__flex:after.dct-cta--signup .dct-cta__label.dct-cta--signup .dct-cta__btn.dct-cta--signup__dialog.dct-cta--signup__dialog--js-active.dct-cta--subscribe .dct-cta__flex.dct-cta__image-wrap.dct-cta--subscribe .dct-cta__image-wrap,.dct-cta--subscribe .dct-cta__content@media only screen and .dct-cta--subscribe--contained .dct-cta__flex.dct-cta--subscribe--contained .dct-cta__image-wrap@media only screen and @supports or.dct-cta__grid:after.dct-cta--signup .dct-cta__label,.dct-cta--signup .dct-cta__btn.dct-cta--signup .dct-cta__gridgrid-template-columns:fr minmaxgrid-gap:.rem .remIt was his love of the seaside that inspired Stephen Collie to start operating his own ice cream bike, which has been a well-loved feature of locals and tourists alike visiting Aberdeen beach over the years.Stephen launched Nostalgic Ice Cream Bike in September  and has been serving traditional dairy ice cream to dessert lovers at the city#s beachfront most weekends ever since.During the weekdays the -year-old, from Aberdeen, is a driver for a local transport company.But it is his weekend venture, which opens from around am or noon to pmon Saturdays and Sundays, that gives Stephen #a lot of satisfaction and pride.#Being an outdoor business, Nostalgic Ice Cream Bike is only open seasonally from March until the end of October.However, Stephen also offers bookings for other events all year round, including weddings, galas, fairs and fundraisers.The bike is based on the old-fashioned Walls ice cream tricycle that was introduced in , which made its way around housing estates across London serving ice cream to locals.#Many of my older customers say the bike brings back memories of their childhood,# Stephen said.#I love hearing their stories.#The idea came from a love of the seaside and enjoying the open air. I used to live in a flat near the beach as a child and my grandparents took me there a lot while my parents were working.#My grandfather was a crane driver at Aberdeen harbour most of his working le until he retired so I#ve always enjoyed watching boats going in and out.#I also found there were many ice cream bikes in the south of England, but none in Aberdeen.#Stephen had wanted to launch his own business for some time, but finally plucked up the courage to start looking into the idea in the winter of .After making contact with the council and environmental health at the start of , and securing relevant licenses and compliance, Nostalgic Ice Cream Bike came into play in September that year.He continued: #I started my own business as a means to get a bit more cash to support my family. The bike has proved to be a welcome attraction in the city so I haven’t really looked back.#Covid took its toll and we lost over  bookings overnight with lockdown, but by serving at the beach it kept us going.#Buying the bike and necessary trailer and equipment plus initial stock was an investment of more than £,.Placing an order in March  for the equipment he was up and running by the autumn.#The bike was hand-built by Lee Hayes of Peddlers Ice Cream near Southampton, while I made the cart using an old bicycle trailer. I made a wood trim to offer more flavours of ice cream,# said Stephen.#The bike has its own modern power system where the freezer can be run on battery power.#It#s great being at the beach watching surfers and swimmers and families enjoying themselves. You also get to spot a dolphin or two, it#s a great way to pass the day.#Stephen serves up ice cream produced by Cream o# Galloway, based at Castle Douglas in Dumfries and Galloway, however he hopes to be able to make and sell his own one day.He said: #We don’t make our own ice cream at present but it’s something we would love to expand into doing.#Cream o# Galloway#s ice cream is made traditionally on a family farm using organic milk from their dairy herd and egg yolks, sugar and natural flavourings.#My partners# family comes from Castle Douglas. On a visit to see them, we went to the Cream o# Galloway visitor centre, sampled the ice cream and fell in love with the flavours. I knew then it was what I wanted to serve.#For other products like cones, sauces, etc., we use Rizza#s of Huntly.##It gives me a lot of satisfaction and pride to know I’ve launched a well-respected business which the community and wider public support.#Visit Nostalgic Ice Cream Bike on Facebook for more information.

action after being left #deeply concerned# by reports of women being spiked by injection in Scottish nightclubs.Health Secretary Humza Yousaf said the Scottish Government was investigating whether current laws were #absolutely robust#.He was quizzed by the BBC after police confirmed they were probing claims that women were spiked using needles in cities across the nation.Askedthe government was considering taking action, Mr Yousaf said: #Yes, is the short answer. I was deeply concerned to read those reports.#Being interviewed on The Sunday Show by Martin Geissler, the health secretary was questioned on what action could be taken.#Again we are looking at the law at the moment to seeit is absolutely robust,# he said.#But I have to say, I know from the justice secretary#s conversations with Police Scotland, they are taking it incredibly, incredibly seriously, and doing whatever is necessary.#And# I should say the conversations I know the justice team have had with the night-time industry too, they are taking it incredibly seriously.#Mr Yousaf added: #We will continue to examine the law and our enforcement activity to make sure it is robust to deal with this.#We will continue to examine the law and our enforcement activity to make sure it is robust to deal with this.#It emerged last week that police were investigating a report of spiking by injection at a venue in Aberdeen.Northsound had spoken to the Aberdeen University student who believes she was spiked by injection during a night out in the city centre.She said: “After a certain time of night, I don’t have any memory or recollection of what happened, the whole night was kind of blacked out.#It wasn’t until the next day when I woke up, that my friends told me what had happened.#There have also been reports of incidents in Dundee, Glasgow and Edinburgh, although police have said they did not believe they were linked.

or.dct-cta__grid:after.dct-cta--signup .dct-cta__label,.dct-cta--signup .dct-cta__btn.dct-cta--signup .dct-cta__gridgrid-template-columns:fr minmaxgrid-gap:.rem .remAberdeen manager Stephen Glass hailed his players’ resolve after enduring one defensive reshuffle after another in their - win against Hibernian.The Dons lost Jack Mackenzie to injury before the game and both Calvin Ramsay and Declan Gallagher were forced off with injuries in the first half of the game at Pittodrie.The loss of the players meant the Dons had to revert to a back three for the second half with team captain Scott Brown deployed as sweeper in the victory.Glass said: “We had to reshape things and boys weren’t playing in natural positions.“In the second half we didn’t have as much possession as we would have liked so we changed the shape a little bit to get more pressure on them.“There were crosses and shots from distance but we didn’t give up a lot of opportunities for them to score.“If we had made the mistakes we had previously, maybe I would be sitting here saying the same things.”With Mackenzie set to see a specialist on Monday to assess the extent of his ankle injury suffered in training on Thursday the Aberdeen manager is fearing the worst.Glass also believes it is unlikely Ramsay and Gallagher will be available for Wednesday’s trip to Ibrox to face Premiership champions Rangers.He said: “I don’t know but I would guess Wednesday would be too quick as two fo them came off.“But I hope that I am wrong.“Jack Mackenzie will be assessed on Monday but it looked like a bad one on Thursday at training.“Sometimes when you are under the cosh things get thrown at you and you have to deal with it.“The players showed they are a group that can play multiple positions which helps.”

or.dct-cta__grid:after.dct-cta--signup .dct-cta__label,.dct-cta--signup .dct-cta__btn.dct-cta--signup .dct-cta__gridgrid-template-columns:fr minmaxgrid-gap:.rem .remAny polls taken on the player of the season so far at Peterhead are likely to include goalkeeper Brett Long right near the top.Time and again this season the Blue Toon have been able to count on the in-form stopper, none more so than Saturday when a string of top saves kept Falkirk at bay.The goal-less draw was preserved chiefly by Long, who denied Declan McDaid, Aidan Nesbitt and Michael Ruth from breaching the Peterhead defence.Since his arrival from East Fe in the summer he has won the battle of the Balmoor goalkeepers, keeping good friend Lenny Wilson on the bench for now.#He#s doing really well # his shot-stopping particular is really good,# said manager Jim McInally. #We#re encouraging to be braver with crosses.#He#s been good and he#s built up a rapport with Lenny . They push each other and even Lenny said to me he doesn#t blame me for picking Brett.#It was not a game which will be remembered for expansive, free-flowing football, owing mainly to the high winds in the north-east, but Peterhead were able to hold their own.Two first-half injuries saw Simon Ferry and Niah Payne replaced, while midfielder Andy McCarthy was removed early in the second half to avoid picking up a second booking. #BlueToon 🔵⚪️💙mdash Peterhead FCOctober , McInally added: #We ended up with a team on the park that was a team of young boys. It was pretty bizarre to be honest.#Grantcame in on in the first half, Lyallhadn#t played for a while and they weren#t where they could be legs-wise. I had to take Andy McCarthy off before he got sent off and with things going wrong, I thought we dealt with it.#We#d been working on dferent shapes and you could tell  minutes into the second half, it was a day for closing ranks a wee bit.#McInally was able to count on another influential performance from teenager Josh Mulligan.The Dundee loanee has made himself an indispensable part of the Peterhead side since ing for a second loan spell at the League One club this season.He has featured mainly at right-back but has also been called upon at centre-half and in midfield, with Mulligan finishing Saturday#s game as a right winger.If he continues on his current form, then once heto Dens Park in the summer he should be in a great position to push on for a first-team place.McInally said: #Considering it wasn#t a game where everything went in his favour today # defensively he#s learning andhe can crack that, he#s going to be some player.#I#m pretty sure he#ll be knocking on the door when he goes back. I think he#s a modern-day right-backhe was a full-back for Celtic or Rangers he would just bomb on every time but at Dundee it#s a bit tougher and you might get exposed defensively.#He#s got such an engine in him and has great pace and strength. If he learns how to be a better defender there#ll be no stopping him.#Peterhead lost Ferry after just  minutes, which required an immediate re-shuffle with winger Grant Savoury coming on.Payne got injured shortly after but was able to continue until half-time, after a nasty-looking roll of his ankle in his own penalty area.McInally said: #Simon#s hamstring tightened up, so we#re hoping that#ll be OK. Niah#s was a horrible-looking one at the time, because a massive mound of turf came up. It looks like he#s damaged the ligaments in his ankle.#

title: star return to league action with victory
story: Colin CameronUpdated:   , : pmLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwards.RJD-sponsored Red Star travelled to Ballerup, East Kilbride on Saturday October  to play their first league game since February  and ed home with three points after an excellent overall performance.The visitors started the game on the front foot and could have been ahead after three minutes when Fraser Talbot#s long range effort came crashing back off the bar.Star didn#t have long to wait before they opened the scoring, however, as Stuart MacLean reacted quickest to a slip in the Duncanrig defence to put his side ahead four minutes later.Talbot again came close to his first Red Star goal but was denied by the crossbar for the second time after finding space to shoot in the box.The lead was doubled soon after when Aaron Moore linked up well with Stuart MacLean on the right channel and powered his shot through the hands of the Duncanrig keeper.Star had several chances to make the game safe in the opening half hour with Craig Aitken and Andy Weir providing the ammunition from the wide areas but the final touch was slightly lacking.Coll McCallum was next to rattle the bar as his long-range effort took a bizzare bounce over the keeper#s head but the woodwork was once again kind to the hosts.Duncanrig pulled themselves back into the game with a rare attack which saw Star switch off and concede a disappointing goal as the midfielder was able to burst through the Star spine unchallenged to leave Ally Lewis with no chance.This stung Star back into action and the two-goal cushion was restored before the break when an excellent counter-attack saw Talbot lay a perfectly weighted pass into the path of Aitken, who finished with great composure to give Star a - lead at half time.Star looked to put the game to bed as quickly as possible in the second half and did so as Aaron Moore grabbed his second of the afternoon following a slip from the Duncanrig keeper.MacLean was next to double his tally as he proved too sharp for the Duncanrig defence and finished well from a tight angle to make the score - with half an hour to go.This gave manager Weir the chance to ring the changes, with Ryan Caskie coming on to replace Aaron Moore and helping himself to two goals of his own from close range to make the final score -.The only sour note was an injury to goal-scoring substitute Caskie which will rule him out of Star#s next game.Star look to make it back-to-back wins on Saturday October , again on their travels to Port Glasgow OBU.

title: argyll teachers to speak at local climate summit
story: Updated:   , : pmLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwards.Subscribe NowArgyll and Bute Council will host its first education climate summit next week with local teachers playing a pivotal role in the event.On October  and  speakers from schools, businesses and charities will address the online event to raise awareness of a broad range of climate issues.Taynuilt teacher Jenner Love will tell those attending about how her pupils have been working with a local textile company to create natural, powerful messages to raise awareness of climate change.Taynuilt Primary School pupils worked with textile company Crubag as part of a project documenting research they had carried out into plastics on their shorelines. The children created mood boards of their findings and created designs using printing techniques taught to them by Crubag.The designs were inspired by the results of their shore investigations, using microscope images of the plastics and materials they had found on the beach. The result was artwork with a powerful message. The designs were printed onto organic cotton and used to cover recycled paper notebooks.Also speaking at the summit will be Rhu Primary School head teacher Linda MacBeath who will talk about the Queen’s Green Canopy project, a tree planting initiative the school has been taking part in.Each session will last approximately one hour and will include presentations by the Scottish Association for Marine Science, ALIEnergy, Wreckspeditions Dive Charters Ltd, Time for Change Argyll and the Hebridean Whale and Dolphin Trust.The council’s policy lead for education Councillor Yvonne McNeilly said: #Argyll and Bute Council has signed up to meet Scotland’s target of achieving ‘net zero’ by . We have one of the lowest carbon footprints anywhere in the UK and I firmly believe thatwe all make some changes, even small ones, we could become the first local authority to achieve ‘net zero’ per head of population.#Education is at the heart of thiswe are to succeed and our schools are already doing amazing things to help raise awareness of global issues in our fight against climate change. This summit will be a great opportunity for our communities to come together and showcase what they are doing to make a dference. It will enable us to unite and highlight the challenges we are facing and what we can all do to help overcome them.#The key speakers taking part in the summit have each geared their presentations towards a specic audience, from school pupils to local businesses, so there is something to interest everyone. I would encourage everyone to sign up to at least one of the sessions to help us build a brighter, greener future for everyone.#The event is free to attend and can be accessed via the council#s website.PICPupils# efforts to play a key role in the education climate summit. no_aClimateSummit

title: peebles-artists-work-display-dawyck-botanic-garden
story: THE curator of a garden near a Borders town says the attraction is ldquovery lucky to be able to show visitors a new collection of artwork.Paintings by Edinburgh landscape artist Sarah Knox are on display at The Studio at Dawyck Botanic Garden, near Peebles.Lost Worlds, a collection of  ldquoinspiring works created during the COVID- pandemic, will be on show until November . It can be viewed from am daily and admission to the exhibition is free.Graham Stewart, curator at Dawyck Botanic Garden, said: ldquoAfter a long delay we are exceedingly happy to welcome Sarah and her amazing artwork to the garden.ldquoIt is very important for us to showcase artists and for our visitors to engage with the media, to inspire them to explore the landscapes around them.:Peebles High School pupil Jamie inspired after meeting musical hero at concertldquoSarah was inspired during lockdown to refocus her work, painting locally and lsquoplein-airrsquo in her immediate surroundings to magnicently capture lovely reflections of nature and space.ldquoHer reflection on the changing world in watercolours, oil paintings and prints really heightens your appreciation for the sheer beauty of our natural environment.ldquoWe feel very lucky to have her work shown here for our visitors to see.Although the pandemic forced the original dates in  to be postponed, since the first lockdown Sarah has refocused her work to reflect her reduced lestyle.She has sketched and painted daily en plein-air in her immediate surroundings such as the gardens in her neighbourhood, weekly visits to the Royal Botanic Garden Edinburgh and Malleny Gardens at Balerno.:lsquoLong waitsrsquo at BGH emergency department due to lsquohigh levels of demandrsquoAt her studio at Beaverhall in Edinburgh, Knox explored new mots for Lost Worlds and through the process of making multiple drawings, paintings and prints she has ldquofound a pictorial language to reflect our feelings of a changed world since the pandemic impacted our daily lives.Although typically renowned for her paintings of wild places in Scotland, during the lockdowns Knox found solace painting in these ldquointimate gardens.She said: ldquoAs the world gradually re-opens, I am delighted to be back immersed in the beauty of Dawyck and to be stepping back out to paint the expansive coasts of Scotland.ldquoWhen painting is going well it feels like I am flying. Itrsquos often the work produced when Irsquom outside with a sketchbook balanced on my lap and the materials at my feet that I relax in nature and produce magical and fluid images of the landscape. I found that being able to visit the Royal Botanic Garden Edinburgh every week throughout lockdown was a privilege as an artist and a leline for mental wellbeing.:Borders pensioner made sexual gestures and exposed himself in front of neighbourSarah added that she was excited to finally exhibit this work at Dawyck and to share how the theme of Lost Worlds emerged as a consequence of her own reduced boundaries during lockdown.Dawyck Botanic Garden is a five-star garden renowned for its seasonal flower displays.The garden is open daily throughout October between am and pm. In November, it will shut at pm.

title: melrose-apartment-complex-work-begins-former-church-site
story: CONSTRUCTION is under way on a new four-floor retirement apartment complex in a Borders town.And developers hope the Melrose project will be completed by Christmas in .The flats will be built on the site of the former church West Grove near the centre of the town.The complex ndash called Westgrove ndash will feature a mix of two and three-bedroom properties, with a new gym and health spa set to be situated behind the apartments.Michael Crawford, managing director at developers Rural Renaissance Limited, said: ldquoWhile Rural Renaissance has been building housing in the Borders since , the new Westgrove project will be our first aimed at those looking to retire.:Man broke court order by speaking to woman outside Galashiels nightclubldquoAs a Borders business, wersquore passionate about the local area. Above providing suitable homes for all, our calculations show that the new development will provide an economic boost for the town with roughly pound.m of investment in the local area.According to the developers, a six-figure package was received from Bank of Scotland to support the project.ldquoBank of Scotland helped massively with setting this project in motion, said Mr Crawford.ldquoThe financial support has given us the ability to push ahead with the build and create a host of new jobs for local people.Rural Renaissance says it has created  jobs and one apprenticeship position to support the project.:Plans backed for new -hour gym to fill empty unit at Galashiels retail parkDouglas Spowart, relationship director at Bank of Scotland, said: ldquoWith the number of people in Scotland aged over  set to rise to around . million over the next  years, the demand for senior living accommodation will likely continue to grow.ldquoThe decision by Rural Renaissance to expand into this sector is therefore a timely one and wersquore proud to have supported the firm with its first retirement project in the Scottish Borders.ldquoThe new Melrose development is another example of the incredible innovation being shown by firms across the country.ldquoAs we look to move beyond recovery and towards growth, wersquoll continue to stand by Scottish businesses looking to innovate and explore new opportunities.Rural Renaissance has seen ldquosubstantial growth in recent years, with a current annual turnover of poundm.The firm is one of the largest property developers in the Borders and has live sites in Melrose, Kelso and Galashiels.

title: a7-selkirk-bypass-calls-continue-following-latest-accident
story: CONCERNS about road safety in a Borders town need to be taken ldquomore seriously, according to an MP for the region.The A action group has been campaigning for a number of years to install a Selkirk bypass to take large vehicles away from the town.Following reports of a man being hit by a lorry while walking on the pavement in the town, political figures have called on the Scottish Government to address the concerns.However, a Transport Scotland spokesperson said it is ldquonot possible to make decisions on specic sections of the A until an appraisal has been completed.The A runs through the centre of the town.:Borders man admits threatening or abusive behaviour towards -year-old girlSupporters of a bypass believe it would help with traffic congestion in Selkirk, as well as improving the town centre environment.On the recently reported incident, Berwickshire, Roxburgh and Selkirk MP John Lamont said: ldquoThese accidents are avoidable, and I would urge the Scottish Government to think again about its priorities with regards to road infrastructure.ldquoI have supported calls for action to be taken on this issue before. However, there is nothing to suggest that it is being treated with any urgency by the Scottish Government.The Conservative representative added: ldquoPeople in Selkirk have already voiced their concerns about the traffic situation in the town. It is time that their concerns are taken more seriously by the Scottish Government.:Work starts on four-floor apartment complex on site of former Borders churchEttrick, Roxburgh and Berwickshire MSP Rachael Hamilton, also of the Conservatives, said: ldquoIt is really worrying that accidents continue to be caused here whilst the SNP government are sitting on their hands over fixing the problem.ldquoThe A action group have been vocal in their calls for a bypass around Selkirkrsquos town centre. This view is mirrored by members of the community in Selkirk. I am disappointed that, despite several warnings, the government here in Scotland is choosing to prioritise other projects over this.Responding to the comments, a Transport Scotland spokesperson said: ldquoThe Borders Transport Corridors Study, published in March , emphasised the importance of a connected, safe, resilient, and high quality strategic transport network for the Scottish Borders.ldquoAmongst its  recommendations were two options for targeted and safety related road improvements on the A.:Background reports ordered into Borders man who admitted motoring offencesldquoThese options included a possible bypass of Selkirk, localised widening, improved overtaking opportunities and a package of measures to improve road safety, these interventions are currently being appraised within Phase  of the second Strategic Transport Projects Review .ldquoUntil the appraisal process is completed, it is not possible to make inidual decisions on improving specic sections of the A, including a Selkirk bypass.The STPR is expected to conclude this winter, with publication of recommendations for investment. This will then be followed by the ldquoappropriate statutory consultation period.Transport Scotland says it is aware of the incident on October  and that it will be included in BEAR Scotlandrsquos annual safety review of the nationrsquos trunk roads.

title: borders-records-60-coronavirus-cases-24-hours
story: THE Borders has recorded  new cases of coronavirusin the last day, latest figures show.According to Scottish Government data published at pm today , the Borders has now seen , cases of the virus since the start of the pandemic.There are currently nine people in the hospital in the Borders with confirmed cases of the virus ndash one more than yesterday.Scotland has now recorded , cases of the virus since March last year, according to the latest data.

title: galashiels-big-night-oot-raise-money-mnd-scotland
story: GALASHIELS is set to host a night of top-quality entertainment to help raise money for MND Scotland.The Big Night Oot, to be held at the MacArts Centre on Saturdayfrom .pm-pm, has been organised by Ross Mackie ndash an NHS mental health team leader ndash in memory of his late friend.The -year-old, of Selkirk, said: ldquoWersquore staging the event in memory of our friend Helen who, together with her husband Calum, were my sonrsquos godparents.ldquoWhen Helen was diagnosed with MND, Calum received support from MND Scotland throughout her illness, and following her death last year. The event is my way of supporting the work that the charity does on a daily basis."The Big Night Oot will include comedy performances from Martin Bearne and Viv Gee, as well as music, special guests and a prize draw.Iain McWhirter, head of fundraising at MND Scotland, said: ldquoIrsquod like to thank Ross for all he is doing to raise awareness of MND and funds to help fight back against motor neurone disease.ldquoItrsquos because of people like Ross that we are able to provide emotional, practical and financial support to families affected by MND, and fund vital MND research.Mr Mackie added: ldquoIrsquod like to thank Morgan Smith, Lee McCleary and my family and friends for helping to organise this event. We hope people will come along on Saturday night for a brilliant evening of laughs, music and charity fundraising for this brilliant cause.Tickets for The Big Night Oot are pound and can be purchased fromwww.ticketsource macartsYou might also be interested in:Selkirk rugby players proud to wear their hearton their sleevesWork starts on four-floor apartment complexon site of former Borders churchSafety concernson major Borders road need to be taken more seriously, says MP

title: galashiels-man-refused-come-interchange-toilets
story: A -YEAR-OLD man locked himself in the toilets at the Galashiels Transport Interchange and refused to come out, Selkirk Sherf Court has been told.John Fernon had been involved in a disturbance the previous day at the Co-operative store in Melrose when he was in possession of a hammer and after being arrested and taken to Hawick Police Station he challenged two police officers to fight.Turning to the events at Galashiels Transport Interchange on February , an inspector noted a man smoking a vape pen in the male toilets area around pm.:Borders man convicted of assault to severe injury and danger to le is jailedJoanne Waller, prosecuting, said: "The accused was told to stop smoking and the accused became threatening towards the inspector. He raised his voice and said to the inspector,Irsquom from Glasgow you f****** b*******.
