The superb fluttering of light was of startling beauty and dazzling splendour, momentarily illuminating the sky from horizon to horizon.Accompanied by this brilliant display of lightscape were sharp cracks and outbursts of thunder, which rumbled, reverberated and re-echoed throughout the landscape with an eerie sort of foreboding effect.The phenomenon was characterised by a high percentage of fork lightning, which is most unusual in our temperate zone.

title: leader october 15
story: It was encouraging to see a positive and constructive debate, with cross-party MSPs from across the region delivering a similar message.What matters now is what happens next.John Gurr, chairman of the Rest and Be Thankful Campaign group, has invited Transport Minister Graeme Dey and the area#s MSPs to join him in a journey along the route, #on the bus too,#desired.Whatever mode of transport Mr Dey choses to take one thing remains certain. Short and long term solutions need to be found and found quickArgyll and Bute is to continue to grow and thrive.•A massive shout out from the Campeltown Courier to all of the award winners at the inaugural Spirit of Campbeltown Awardsheld in the Town Hall last Saturday night and an equally huge well done to Cheryl Lang who created and organised the event.Finally thank you to all the members of the public who voted for the winners in each category and all those who supported the event. Truly heart warming indeed.

title: letters october 15 2021
story: I am writing this letter due to concern and disgust at the state of Kilkerran Cemetery, Campbeltown, lately.When entering the cemetery, there the workmen#s tractor, vans and trailers are parked, even at the end of the work day, and a mound of earth which has been there for some time and in fact has weeds growing at the back of it.Leaves off the palm trees are strewn all over the road and grass.Regarding the vans, trailers and tractor, they make it dficult to drive your car in the cemetery and do not help with the appearance. Surely they could be stored at the council depot, especially when not getting used.The grass throughout was cut and the loose grass was left lying in thick clumps, asit was a playing field, instead of a cemetery.This cemetery, in years past, won an award but I fail to see the same happening again with things as they are of late.The grass around the stones, at the sides and back, is not being cut, resulting in long grass and often ferns growing there are bollards lying loose which will undoubtedly result in damage to a car there are cones at the main car park, restricting the amount of cars that can park there, and there are also cones at the portable cabins the road in the cemetery is a total disgrace!I in no way blame the men who work in the cemetery as they are doing as they have been told to do, and I know they are taken from the cemetery to work where, resulting in those men not having the time to complete the work which is necessary to keep the cemetery in the condition it should be.I understand about cutbacks and lack of funds but I am wondering where the money goes that people have paid for plots and or council tax, which increase and yet there are even more cutbacks.My biggest concern is where has the respect gone The following is in response to the debate about the state of the A over Rest And Be Thankful in the Scottish Parliament last Wednesday, October .I fear that the current Rest and Be Thankful is a catastrophe waiting to happen and I think that there needs to be an urgency from the Scottish Government to deliver a medium-term and long-term solution for the people and businesses of Argyll.The Cabinet Secretary discussed the necessity to collect data for the end long-term solution and, as much as I appreciate that, it should have been done years ago and I completely understand the frustrations felt by businesses and travellers alike.The Cabinet Secretary also invited all contributing MSPs to walk the forestry road with engineers and I am going to write to him to accept that invitation.

title: photograph of the week october 15 2021
story: Graham took several nature and scenic shots while visiting south Kintyre recently, another of which we published last month.If you have a photograph you would like to share, please email it to editor@campbeltowncourier or send it via the Courier#s Facebook page.

title: tale of two halves as pupils lose out in paisley
story: Campbeltown Pupils suffered late heartbreak last Saturday as they suffered a reverse away result to Paisley outfit Glenvale.Leading - at half time, the Pupils played well beneath their top level in the second half and succumbed to a late goal at Ferguslie Sports Centre to lose -.Travelling with a strong squad of , the Pupils looked determined in the first half to take three points back to Kintyre.Moving the ball with precision and purpose the McFadyens-sponsored Pupils were well on top and made a great start within  minutes when Liam Renton’s corner found Ross Souden in the box and the young central defender forced the ball into the net.The Pupils’ front three of Rhys Casci, Scott Souden and Renton were in full flow, keeping the Glenvale defence facing their own goal and latching on to some well-aimed distribution from goalkeeper Alasdair Ferguson.The Pupils doubled their lead before half-time when holding midfielder Ellis Robertson broke free of his marker and guided a sublime curling effort into the Glenvale keeper’s top left-hand corner.What followed in the second half, however, was bitterly disappointing.After fending off some early pressure from their hosts, the Pupils retreated which only served to embolden Glenvale, and sure enough before the hour, their first goal arrived after an onrushing midfielder drove home a low shot from just inside the penalty box.The Pupils struggled for a foothold as the second half progressed, their fluidity furtherMidfielder Stuart Crossan also received a nasty kick to the ankle in attempting to block a Glenvale effort, and was replaced by young forward Conner McMurchy.With only a few minutes remaining, Glenvale scored a third when a through-ball was erted into the path of a Glenvale winger, who burst forward to score.On reflection, it was a confusing Jekyll-and-Hyde performance from the Kintyre Park side, with lessons to be learned in maintaining a level of performance for  minutes.Tomorrowthe Pupils will travel to Petershill Park, Glasgow, for perhaps the most high-profile competitive match in the club’s history to date, when they take on Premier Division Rossvale FC of Bishopbriggs in the WOSFL’s league cup.Those who would like to travel to the game to support the Pupils should check @PupilsAFC and @RossvaleJFC on Twitter for postcode details, or see Campbeltown Football on Facebook.

title: thought for the week october 15 2021
story: One morning recently, I heard the following two news items on the radio:First was a report about the petrochemical plant at Grangemouth which emits tons of CO into the atmosphere. There are plans to convert it to a hydrogen plant which would capture the CO, send it along a pipeline to Aberdeenshire ready for it to be stored deep under the sea.That was immediately followed by a report on the shortage of CO caused by the increase in energy costs and the closing down of two fertilizer factories which send CO on to other industries, in particular food.How ironic – one industry wants to bury the stuff that others desperately need!I decided to find out more and discovered that CO in ying grades of purity is used in a wide iety of industries.On further research, I also discovered that CO is already being turned from a pollutant into a resource.Companies around the world, including the UK, are reusing CO to make building blocks, cement, foam housing insulation and fuel.I found two examples of companies feeding CO to algae, one to make carbon fibre and the other to revive oyster reefs.#Now it is required that those who have been given a trust must prove faithful.# We are all responsible for the care of our planet, whether as members of faith groups or members of a global society.Refining CO might cost a fortune but not doing so could cost the earth.

title: west coast motors 100 years of bringing people together part i
story: A century after Campbeltown-based coach operator West Coast Motors was founded, bus enthusiast Lawrence Macduff, who splits his time between Kilmarnock and Dunoon, has penned a commemorate article delving into the company#s history from  to the present day.The piece, and several photographs also supplied by Lawrence, will be published in the Courier over the next few weeks.There cannot be too many businesses in the whole of Argyll which have been able to celebrate  years of continuous trading.Of these, West Coast Motors, as the principal bus service provider not only for residents of Kintyre but nowadays for the majority of Argyll folks, has a very conspicuous profile simply by the very nature of what it does.If its family founders were alive today, I#m sure they would feel a sense of great pride at the achievements of their progeny in building the West Coast business into the major transport enterprise it now is.By way of an introduction, this writer is not a native of the #Wee Toon# but my cousin first came to live in Campbeltown in  and thus I have a great affinity with the area.Furthermore, since boyhood, I#ve had a deep-rooted interest in #the buses#, not just in Kintyre but across the western seaboard and the western and northern isles.Thus it was that this enthusiast, following a -year career in banking – including two weeks# duty in Campbeltown  years ago – came to take up bus driving professionally when I retired in you are going to be smitten with a hobby that has also become your job, you might as well go the whole hog.I have been involved in bus preservation for more than  years. My preserved  MacBraynes coach was built for the Campbeltown–Glasgow service in , and was joined in  by my now restored West Coast Motors DAF service coach that spent a chunk of its working le in Campbeltown.And, so, to this brief historical commentary. So much has happened within a century in every walk of le and West Coast Motors# history reflects this.Space can only allow me to touch on the bare details over such an extended period but for anyone who would like to know more, Venture Publications and writer Ian Stubbs in  released an excellent history of West Coast#s operations with its title A celebration of  years# service.I believe the publisher still has some copies in stock, and it may also be obtainable second-hand. I have referred to this excellent record in providing information for this historical résumé.A further detailed company history is being prepared, though the rapidity with which West Coast#s evolution takes place means that it is hard to ever regard any such work as complete!Suffice it to say that John, David and William Craig, having formed a garage repair business just after the end of the First World War, then ventured into the realms of road passenger transport in February  by launching a service between Campbeltown and Tarbert to compete with Duncan Ramsay, an existing operator on this route.The Post Office then put out to tender its mail contract to meet the steamer at Tarbert. It was secured by what became the second of the famous Kintyre passenger transport company names, A  P McConnachie.Further new operators joined the fray and, as was common in those days, intense competition occurred everywhere in the country until regulatory route licensing was introduced in  with the arrival of the Road Traffic Act.Post Office mails and parcels contracts formed a key part of the Kintyre service network in a similar but much further reaching geographical spread, the now famous MacBraynes organisation of those times similarly carried parcels and mails to destinations across the western seaboard and western isles in its own fleet of buses and motor ships.In the mid-s,West Coast Motors obtained a contract to convey mails and parcels to and from Campbeltown and Glasgow. This was renewed at succeeding intervals and continued right up until .The vans and light trucks later used were every bit as smartly turned out as the coaches, and were an excellent advert for the company.To be continued in next week#s Courier.

title: whats on at campbeltown picture house
story: Ron’s Gone Wrong is the story of Barney, a socially awkward middle-schooler and Ron, his new walking, talking, digitally-connected device, which is supposed to be his ‘Best Friend out of the Box.’ Ron’s hilarious mals set against the backdrop of the social media age, launch them into an action-packed journey in which boy and robot come to terms with the wonderful messiness of true friendship.Previews From ThursdayDirected by Denis Villeneuve Dune tells the story of Paul Atreides, a brilliant and gted young man born into a great destiny beyond his understanding, who must travel to the most dangerous planet in the universe to ensure the future of his family and his people. As malevolent forces explode into conflict over the planet#s exclusive supply of the most precious resource in existence # a commodity capable of unlocking humanity#s greatest potential # only those who can conquer their fear will survive.

title: campbeltown and tarbert team takes argyll bowls trophy
story: Eighteen teams participated on the day with four progressing to the semi-finals.The first semi-final was between B Dalziel Senior, J McCormick, A Johnston and B Dalziel Junior and S Grumoli, K Kerr, D Reid and G McLachlan Junior who eventually took the win -.The second semi-final was between G McLachlan Senior, J D McCallum, J McLachlan and B Mathieson versus Tarbert Bowling Club#s K Prentice, A Ronald and J Martin and K Anderson of Campbeltown Bowling Club, with the latter rink taking the win -.The final was a close game with John Martin#s team taking a three in the first end before Gavin McLachlan Junior#s team took a four in end two to take a narrow lead.Both teams exchanged the next three ends with John#s team taking a narrow - lead going into the last end.Gavin#s team lay two for the game but the Tarbert back end managed to get the shot back and hold on for the win -.An Argyll Bowling Club spokesperson said: #It was another fantastic competition thanks to a great local entry from both Campbeltown clubs and teams travelling from Menstrie, Cambus, Burnbank, Wellcroft and Tarbert bowling clubs.#We would like to thank Glen Scotia Distillery for its amazing continued support of our annual fours competition.#We also want to thank those members who helped with the bar and the kitchen, keeping us well fuelled for the day#s play, and Bobby for preparing the green for the day.#

title: deliver permanent solution to the rest debacle by 2024 demand petitioners
story: It asks the Scottish Parliament to urge Transport Minister Graeme Dey MSP and the Scottish Government to recognise #the crisis# at the Rest and Be Thankful as an emergency due to the economic and environmental impacts and the #high risk# that , tonnes of debris is ready to fall which could be a #risk to le#.John Gurr, the campaign group#s chairperson, said: #We ask that Graeme Dey MSP and the Scottish Government deliver a robust two-way temporary alternative to the A by  – the current mitigation works of planting trees and digging pits does not stop landslides or stop the road from being closed every time it rains.#We ask Graeme Dey MSP and the Scottish Government to stop wasting time on y consultation and deliver a permanent solution by .#Prior to the petition being launched, the campaign group, which includes several Kintyre business-owners, engaged with local councillors and MSPs to raise support.This led to a meeting with Transport Scotland and Mr Dey, who, according to the group, #will not alter their current plans to continue closing when it rains, without a suitable temporary solution, and will not rethink the y project to decide on a permanent solution#.On Tuesday, the day after the petition was launched, road maintenance firm BEAR Scotland announced that the A at the Rest was to close overnight from pm, with the single-track Old Military Road ersion route used as a #safety precaution# as a result of continuing heavy rain.BEAR Scotland#s North West representative Eddie Ross said that with further heavy rain expected to move through the area over the remainder of the week, safety inspection teams would remain on #high alert#.#The A from Tarbet to the Rest and Be Thankful provides essential road access to and from Argyll,# said Mr Gurr. #Landslides and subsequent road closures are not a new problem here.#Ten years ago the Scottish Government set out options for a permanent solution, yet since then more than £ million of taxpayers# money has been wasted on temporary mitigation.#The road is used by . million vehicles annually, yet was closed for  days last year, creating an unnecessary barrier to our region.#Furthermore, we know that , tonnes of debris is ready to fall. This is a risk to le and should therefore be treated as an emergency and addressed with the urgency that it deserves, yet Transport Scotland are now proposing a further  years to deliver a permanent solution.#In a bid to raise awareness of the petition and the Rest and Be Thankful #debacle#, the campaign group delivered information flyers to , homes across Argyll this week.Within a couple of days of going live, the petition had received more than , signatures.To add your signature, visit https:chng.it RQDnNHcdf

title: from our files october 22 2021
story: Campbeltown fish quay was buzzing last week, with more than  fishing boats in overnight last Monday.There were  Irish fishing boats from Portavogie, Kilkeel and Ardglass, as well as  of the local fleet.They were landing in Campbeltown and it was a busy night for the boys working at the fish market.Harbour master Stephen Scally said it was great seeing Campbeltown busy with fishing vessels and landing good catches again the pier was buzzing with crews and workers.The first heavy rain storm of winter hit Kintyre this week, topping up the rain gauges and flooding fields and roads.Parts of Kilkenzie and Bellochantuy were covered in deep surface water and all fields and burns were swollen with water to bursting point in places.By Tuesday,  days into October, the monthly rainfall had beaten that of September.Harbour master Stephen Scally reports that in the  hours between midday on Monday and Tuesday . inches of rain fell, taking the October total so far to five inches in September there was only . inches for the whole month.At Campbeltown Airport, the anemometer was hitting  knots,  mph, during gusts of wind.And the bad news is this weekend could see more bad weather, with meteorologists watching two low-pressure systems which could be the starting point for another severe storm.TWENTY-FIVE YEARS AGOSpeculation continues over the future of the Keil Hotel following the announcement last week that an interim liquidator had been appointed for Premier Cuisine.It had initially arisen because it was believed Premier Cuisine was the parent company of Keil Leisure, the firm which is undertaking the refit of the Keil Hotel.Keil Leisure announced in February this year it would be carrying out the £ million refit of the Keil Hotel in Southend with plans to turn it into a four-star hotel and country club.However, when the Courier spoke to Mr Brian Morton, the managing director of Premier Cuisine, this week, he denied any link between the two companies.And he stressed the refurbishment of the Keil Hotel was still going ahead by Keil Leisure and that nothing had changed.The official public notice which had sparked off the worries was published in the Glasgow Herald last week on behalf of HM Commissioners of Customs and Excise.The notice gives details of the proposed winding up of Premier Cuisine and the appointment of an interim liquidator following the presentation of a petition to the sherf at Glasgow and Strathkelvin on September .A Customs and Excise spokesman said the case was most definitely live and that they would be proceeding with it to recoup their money which he described as #a substantial amount#.FIFTY YEARS AGOCampbeltown#s first traffic warden began patrolling the burgh streets on Monday.He is Mr Albert Brown, of Kildonald Cottage, by Peninver. Mr Brown and his we came to live at the cottage about a year ago from Erskine, Renfrewshire.Mr Brown spent last week at Argyll County Police Headquarters in Lochgilphead before commencing his duties in the town.In an interview, Mr Brown said he found Campbeltown drivers very co-operative and he has had no trouble with motorists.He does not think there is a serious traffic problem in Campbeltown and says there is ample parking space in side streets.Because of this, there is no reason why motorists should contravene the no-waiting orders, he said.Mr Brown is also responsible for directing a steady flow of traffic through the burgh at peak times and has been on points duty several times.Should Mr Brown find himself left with no alternative but to #book# a motorist, his report goes to the local police station and is dealt with there. He has the full backing of the police. It is hoped he will have a personal two-way radio soon.Mr Brown feels traffic lights would serve a useful purpose at the Longrow South and Main Street junction.Mr Brown served throughout the last war in the th Marine Commandos, when he was awarded the Military Medal.ONE HUNDRED YEARS AGOA further reduction in the price of Drumlemble coal has been made this week. The local fuel is now to be had at s d a ton, or s d a cwt, delivered.The villa Craigowan, which belonged to the late Mr Robert Hogarth, has, we understand, been purchased by the proprietors of Hazelburn Distillery.Herring fishing is almost at a standstill in the local waters. Last week, only  baskets were landed at s a basket. This week so far has been absolutely blank.Another fine addition has been made to the Campbeltown fishing fleet. Mr John Cameron, Bolgam Street, has bought the Girvan boat Alipede I from Mr A M McCrindle. She is a nice boat, fitted with a - Kelvin engine.Mr Peter Dewar, who was president of the Campbeltown and District Football Association for the past two years, has been presented by the association with a smoker#s outfit on the occasion of his leaving for a new appointment in Islay. From his friends in the Liberal Club, Mr Dewar has received a travelling bag as a parting gt.[Editor#s note: Today, smoking is actively discouraged as a health risk but a century ago it was considered acceptable a smoker#s companion or outfit was a matching decorative set of ashtrays, match holders, tobacco, cigar or cigarette boxes and a pipe rack.]The luck of the draw in the Scottish Junior Cup competition has been going strongly in favour of Grammar School Former Pupils. For the third time they have been drawn at home. Their opponents in the third round are Ardeer. The fixture has to be played before November .Argyll Mountain Battery has won the Brigade trophy competed for by the three batteries of the st Highland Mountain Brigade RGAwhile in camp at Buddon. The Ross Battery carried out its practice early in August, while the Argyll and Bute batteries competed during the last fortnight in September. The winning of this trophy reflects the greatest credit on the young gunners who so efficiently manned the battery#s guns during the practice and it will also give pleasure to the old gunners of pre-war days to know the young generation is proving worthy successors.

title: letters october 22 2021
story: It was great to speak to my constituents in Carradale on my latest visit to the village last Saturday.Many residents mentioned the need to cut the grass verges, especially at junctions, for safety reasons. I have contacted Argyll and Bute Council#s roads management about this on numerous occasions and will continue to do so.I have also been in contact with East Kintyre Community Council about the state of signs at passing places in the area. There are roughly  passing places, some with no signs, some with old and badly deteriorated posts and some with new signs.With the increase in use of many East Kintyre roads, it makes sense to have clearly marked passing places.With more and more people working from home, fit-for-purpose broadband speeds and mobile phone coverage is not just a luxury, but an essential tool for day-to-day le. I have been lobbying BT Openreach and local and national governments for more digital investment in our rural ward.I will continue to work day-in and day-out for our area, making sure voices in Kintyre and the islands are heard.As a clinical nurse specialist on Breast Cancer Now#s helpline, I#m acutely aware of the shattering impact of the Covid- pandemic on the emotional wellbeing of people with breast cancer.News of a diagnosis can be a lonely experience and the pandemic has, at times, exacerbated this, denying people the chance to be with loved ones.We#ve seen a sharp rise in calls to our helpline and emails to our Ask Our Nurses service from people struggling emotionally. Many say the loneliness they#ve felt living with breast cancer during the pandemic has been the hardest emotional impact to cope with and that it has negatively impacted their mental health.As many of us look ahead to a #new normal# beyond the pandemic, we must acknowledge the loneliness legacy facing people who#ve lived with breast cancer through the pandemic and commit to addressing it.This Breast Cancer Awareness Month, we want to remind everyone affected by breast cancer that we#re always with you, in every way we can.Thanks to support from players of People#s Postcode Lottery, our online support services are one click away for anyone after a breast cancer diagnosis.Whether you#re a younger woman, adjusting to le after treatment, or living with incurable secondary breast cancer, our tailored support provides a confidential, safe space to connect with others and access specialist information.Find out more about Younger Women Together, Moving Forward, Someone Like Me, and Living With Secondary Breast Cancer at breastcancernow.org online-services

title: west coast motors 100 years of bringing people together part ii
story: A century after Campbeltown-based coach operator West Coast Motors was founded, bus enthusiast Lawrence Macduff, who splits his time between Kilmarnock and Dunoon, has penned a commemorate article delving into the company#s history from  to the present day.The piece, and several photographs also supplied by Lawrence, is being published in the Courier. Look out for the third and final piece in next week#s paper.Wartime needs created additional traffic and pressures for the two main operators, thereafter, once into peacetime, West Coast Motors and its rival were able to modernise their fleets.McConnachie#s stole a march by bringing Kintyre#s first double decker to the town in , buying two more in the late s which older residents may still remember. However, failing general economics resulted in West Coast acquiring this business in . These #deckers never ran for West Coast and it would be more than  years later before such buses entered their fleet.Liveries iniably provide a recognisable identity for any bus operator and West Coast is no exception. The flowering of the company#s one surely came to its climax in the s with the flowing combination of ivory, red and maroon, set off by polished body trim lines and wheel embellishers. Styles continue to evolve but, in the opinion of this writer, no other Scottish operator has chosen a more distinctive colour scheme than West Coast which still uses two of those principal colours, ivory and red, which it bestowed on its buses  years earlier.During the s and s, West Coast#s modern vehicles were typical examples of their time. In the latter period, new bus grants were obtainable under certain conditions resulting in some splendid coaches being purchased.In post war years, the company gradually built on its service network in Kintyre and Mid Argyll. In , it picked up the East Loch – West Loch Tarbert mail ship link from Tarbert-based Dickies then the Tarbert – Kilberry service from McEacherns in , the Lochgilphead Tayvallich service from McLachans in  and, perhaps somewhat prophetically, the Benderloch-based operations of McColls in .Without doubt, the most signicant developments in West Coast#s history occurred in the - period. During the s, William Craig had attempted to introduce a direct Campbeltown to Glasgow service but failed in this ambition then and at later attempts. Finally, in , these hopes were realised when the company became a joint operator, with Scottish Citylink, of the through service between the two locations.The s continued to see signicant developments. Firstly the acquisition, also in , of the buses and Mid Argyll routes operated by Lochgilphead-based Stag Garage. This was followed, a year later, by the purchase of the old MacBrayne garage in Ardrishaig, giving West Coast an excellent base in the area.The early s saw a further involvement in Oban when West Coast secured responsibility for the Oban to Glasgow service and by  it had acquired the former Alexanders depot in Oban enabling it to build further on its already signicant presence in Argyll.Since , the rate of change has quickened further. West Coast secured the Cowal and Bute area contracts and depots in  and when Bowmans, the long-established Mull services operator retired in , West Coast added this to its portfolio. Their Oban base allows vehicle and manpower deployments on Mullneeded. Of the major Argyll islands, only Islay remains independently served by the Mundell concern of Tarbert, whose lorries are also a familiar sight in the county.

title: arkell takes dunaverty golf clubs october medal
story: Lee Mathieson, first man out, took full advantage of the conditions to record the lowest gross score of the day.He completed the first nine in  strokes which included three birdies and one bogey.Despite having a double bogey at the th and a bogey at the th, two birdies on the way back helped him to  strokes.Donald MacNeil was next best, concluding his round in  strokes, having had two bogies on the front and back nines.James Finlay, out in the sixth group, set a nett target of  for those following him to chase.Match secretary Alex Arkell responded in exemplary fashion by not only posting the third lowest gross score of  but also taking the lead from James with a winning nett .Result:  Alex Arkell -  James Finlay -  John Dreghorn -   Lee Mathieson - Bill Brannigan -  Sandy Watson -.Gross:  Lee Mathieson   Donald MacNeil   Alex Arkell  Keith Crawford   Ross Sinclair   Alistair McConnachie .

title: carradale beach proposal katie said yes
story: In two weeks, the couple are moving to Melbourne, Australia, where Katie is from originally.Before they leave, Fraser wanted to pop the question in Carradale, where he has spent many family holidays at his parents# caravan.Despite Monday#s wet and windy weather, nothing could dampen the newly engaged couple#s spirits.

title: leader october 22 2021
story: It is dficult to understand the Scottish Conservative and Unionist Party#s decision not to allow Donald Kelly to represent the party at the  local election – especially when it will not provide a reason.Councillor Kelly said he met #a wall of silence# when asking for a proper explanation or justication, and the Courier has had a similar experience, with numerous attempts to gain answers proving unsuccessful.We asked why the decision was made and why Councillor Kelly was not made aware or given notice of itit was in relation to his Argyll First membership and why support from former Scottish Conservative leaders Annabel Goldie and Ruth Davidson appeared not to be taken into consideration.If we do receive answers to our questions, we will share them with our readers but until then we can only speculate.Surely Councillor Kelly and the people of South Kintyre deserve to know.Congratulations to Fraser Cursiter and Katie Webster who got engaged this week after Fraser proposed on the beach in Carradale.We wish the couple, who are soon moving to Australia, the best of luck for the future we hope theyto visit the place that has earned a special place in their hearts.

title: photograph of the week october 22 2021
story: It shows one of a family of otters that lives on Gigha going for a dip in a freshwater pool.Keith looked for a likely spot for otters to visit and set up his Campark T camera in expectation and his efforts were well rewarded.As well as otters, this spot also attracted geese, a heron, a mink, a young buzzard and a iety of small birds.If you have a photograph you would like to share, please email it to editor@campbeltowncourier or send it via the Courier#s Facebook page.

title: pupils out of cup at hands of high class team
story: Campbeltown Pupils exited the South Challenge Cup in the second round last Saturday, after a six-goal defeat to ex-Junior side Rossvale.The north Glasgow outfit, who play in the West of Scotland Football League#s premier ision – three leagues above the Pupils – scored four goals in a clinical first half.However, the Pupils competed well and had a few efforts at goal themselves, with Ryan Deans floating a shot narrowly over the bar midway through the first half.The McFadyens-sponsored Pupils had travelled with a squad deprived of several first-team players through injury and they were further hindered within ten minutes when holding midfielder Ellis Robertson rolled his ankle and had to be withdrawn.The Pupils went one goal down early on when a Rossvale winger rounded Pupils keeper Alasdair Ferguson and trickled a low shot into the net.Rossvale#s second and third goals were from two crosses, the third perhaps most disappointingly from an unchallenged header, off a delivery from a wide free kick.Another goal followed for Rossvale#s lone striker who evaded the Pupils defence to beat Ferguson with a downward header to make it -.Despite a four-goal deficit at half time, the Pupils continued to battle in the second half and made further inroads into the Rossvale area, with Rhys Casci and Keith Mitchell having efforts at goal with left-footed half volleys which just wouldn#t dip in time to trouble the home keeper.The Feathers Inn-sponsored Pupils were also impressive at the back in the second half, doing well to repel a number of Rossvale attacks from wide areas.It was only through a generous deflection that the hosts made it - with  minutes played, after a long-range effort arced beyond Ferguson into his top right-hand corner, after nicking off a Pupils defender.Then, on  minutes, the sixth and final Rossvale goal was scored after Ferguson#s save from a striker#s shot rebounded off the post and into the path of a grateful Rossvale winger, who slotted into the net from point-blank range.Overall, the Pupils can reflect on a respectable cup performance,not a giant-killing, against an established semi-professional outfit, especially with an injury-ravaged squad, as the Kintyre Park club adapts to its busiest fixture schedule in its years in amateur football, with  competitive matches already played by mid-October.Despite the heavy defeat for the Pupils on the field, one notable footnote to the game was the presence of former Tarbert AFC and Pupils player Reverend John McGregor, who is club chaplain for Rossvale, having performed the same role at Dumbarton FC in previous years.After the match, he met and chatted with the Pupils management and the current Pupils squad#s Tarbert contingent, Lewis McNaughton and Rhys Casci.Tomorrow, Saturday, the Pupils are back on league duty, travelling to Paisley to play St Peter#s FC. Kick off is pm.For more information, see @PupilsAFC on Twitter or Campbeltown Football on Facebook.

title: thought for the week october 22 2021
story: As we crossed the bridge, we were excited to see the island’s beauty.At first though, we had to take our friend’s word for it, as rain, low cloud and failing light obscured most of it from view. The next day the rain stopped, the clouds lted and the sun broke through.We saw for ourselves that what our friend had said was true. Skye’s scenery is stunning.In John, chapter , verses -, the apostles told Thomas that while he had been away, Jesus had physically appeared to them. Thomas refused to accept as true what they told him, insisting that unless he saw him with his own eyes and touched him with his own hands, he would not believe Jesus was alive.For him, seeing was believing.Later, Jesus once again appeared to the apostles and, this time, Thomas was present. Now Thomas believed. Jesus rebuked him for his unbelief and said: ‘Blessed are those who have not seen yet believe.’We believe lots of things, not because we can see them for ourselves but by accepting the word of those who have.Christians believe in Jesus, not because we have seen him with our own eyes, but because of the reliable word of the apostles who physically saw the risen Jesus with their own eyes.I encourage you to read the Gospels, the accurately written-down eyewitness testimony of the apostles to Jesus so that you might see who he is and as you trust in him alone,

title: minato-sushi-cheese-lady-boost-haddington-town-centre
story: The Cheese Lady on Haddington High Street is moving into the former butcher premises of Colin D Peat on neighbouring Court Street.The move from High Street has opened the door for Minato Sushi to bring the Japanese delicacy to the town centre.The changing face of the town centre was welcomed by councillors Tom Trotter and John McMillan, with the new businesses set to open this summer.Jen Kerr, of Minato Sushi, stressed there was still plenty of work ahead at the business before the doors opened.The -year-old, of Port Seton, who will run the business with her boyfriend Tom Cuddy, described it as ldquoa real dream come true.She said: ldquoWe are really excited. It is quite a big town centre in East Lothian and has quite a erse mix of businesses there already. It seems nice and some people have been coming up and chatting to me and other shop owners have been quite friendly.Meanwhile, Svetlana Kukharchuk ndash The Cheese Lady ndash has ambitious plans for the former butchers having found a home for her business in the town nearly four years ago.She said: ldquoWe needed more space and wanted to expand so we can offer more space to our customers to shop more conveniently.ldquoWe want to mature our own cheeses and we are going to have a maturation room.ldquoAlso, Irsquom hoping to offer a few tables, which still needs to be confirmed with the council, where people can sit down and order a flight of cheese and a glass of wine.Svetlana, who previously had a business in St Andrews, moved to East Lothian in November  and opened her High Street shop.The business has proven a popular addition to the town centre, offering cheeses from throughout Europe, including Italy, France, Spain, Switzerland and Norway.Mr Trotter was pleased with the announcement regarding the two businesses.He said: ldquoWhoever thought a cheese shop in Haddington that, after this time, needed bigger premises  Thatrsquos fantastic.ldquoAnd it is incredible we are getting a sushi shop.Fellow ward member Mr McMillan was pleased with the level of interest from people looking to open up businesses in the town.He said: ldquoI think we are in a good place.ldquoWhen we were growing up, we did not know what sushi was!

title: youngsters-12-hour-non-stop-relay-boosts-walk-scott-foundation
story: Mary Kidd spent a day running, cycling, skipping and more in aid of the Walk With Scott Foundation.The -hour non-stop relay on May  has collected more than pound,, which will go to the Tranent-based charity.Proud mum Karen is secretary of the Walk With Scott Foundation, which was set up by after-dinner speaker Scott Glynn to mark his th birthday.Karen thanked everyone who sponsored her -year-old daughter, who also undertook a fundraiser for the charity last year during lockdown.Karen said: ldquoWe are all so very proud of Mary once again, with her amazingly crazy two fundraising events.ldquoMary has raised a fantastic pound, for the Walk with Scott Foundation and I know first-hand how much these funds are going to help others across our communities.Last year, the primary six pupil at Cockenzie Primary School completed a six-hour TikTok marathon, which raised pound, for the Walk With Scott Foundation.: Familys television appearanceThe success of the fundraiser even caught the attention of former Spandau Ballet and EastEnders star Martin Kemp and his son Roman. Mary and Karen were joined by dad Gordon and older sister Abbie on Martin and Romanrsquos Sunday Best TV show to discuss the success of the event.However, Mary was not content to put her feet up and was once again doing her bit for the good cause.Speaking ahead of the latest fundraiser, Mary said: ldquoThis year I want to double the time, and plan to do a -hour non-stop fun relay up and down our Lorimer Lane at the back of my house.ldquoIrsquom walking, running, skipping, hopping, jumping, scootering, cycling, skating, football dribbling, swing ball, space hopping and, of course, TikTok-ing!People can still sponsor Mary by going to uk.virginmoneygiving marysfunrelay

title: eyesore-stadium-structure-pulled-houses-built
story: Scottish housebuilder Ambassador Living is set to break ground on fields at Barbachlaw Farm to provide a mixture of three, four and five-bedroom homes, including  affordable homes.The new development, called Wallace Park, will see two executive show homes launched next summer.Initial clearance will now start on site, including the demolition of the nearby steel structure of the greyhound stadiumrsquos proposed main stand, which has stood as an lsquoeyesorersquo for  years, at Victory Lane.The greyhound stadium project was officially scrapped only recently ndash  years after its plans were first put forward.The Courier previously reported that the firm behind the greyhound stadium, Sirius Sport and Leisure, successfully applied to build housing on adjoining land at Barbachlaw Farm over the years, arguing that it was the only way to fund the project.However, the housing was tied into an agreement with East Lothian Council that the racing venue would be built.The council has agreed to release the firm from the obligation after it applied for a change to conditions to allow family butcher John Gilmour to take over the land.It was revealed that John Gilmour Butchers had come to a conditional agreement with Sirius Sport and Leisure to take on the stadium site.In a statement lodged with the council in support of the application, the family butcherrsquos firm said it intended to move its Macmerry operations to the site so that it could expand.The firm wants to create a new butchery, a processing facility for a new range of plant-based foods, a deli, food hall and create  new jobs.Ambassador Living has also acquired land, separate from the stadium site, for the new housing.Gordon Coster, the companyrsquos managing director, said: ldquoWe are delighted to have successfully acquired the land for our new development in East Lothian.ldquoThis exciting acquisition will now allow us to move forward with creating a stunning new aspirational neighbourhood focusing on spacious modern living.ldquoWe are looking forward to bringing the premium offering from Ambassador Living to East Lothian and introducing buyers to the high-quality specication and finishes on offer within our homes.ldquoWe have enjoyed a great deal of early interest in this development, which lies in the heart of an important growth area.ldquoWith its proximity to Edinburgh and well-established amenities and good schooling options, we expect this only to increase as we move towards our sales launch and invite homebuyers to register their interest early.A dedicated marketing suite at Wallace Park ndash the companyrsquos first East Lothian development ndash is set to open this winter.

title: santa-elves-plan-tour-town
story: Plans are currently under way for a tour of the town by Santa Claus and his elves this Christmas, after the success of the tour last December, when Santa and friends spread festive cheer to children and adults alike.This year, he willwith a new route around the town.The event, organised by local resident Paula Waugh, will see the route, date and times announced in early December.Paula confirmed that Eva the Sat-Nav Elf would update residents about the whereabouts of Santa on social media every  minutes, to ensure people would not be standing out in the cold for too long.She added: ldquoWe look forward to spreading the Christmas cheer around all the good folk of Tranent.

title: section-a1-closed-resurfacing
story: BEAR Scotland will work on the stretch of road between Dolphingstone and Wallyford junctions.The work will take place during the night and will result in the closure of the westbound carriageway of the A between both junctions from pm to am each night, from October  to November .A ersion, taking motorists onto the A and A, will be signposted between the two junctions.The ersion will add approximately six minutes to affected journeys.Emergency services will be given access through the works at all times.Tommy Deans, BEAR Scotlandrsquos south east network manager, said: ldquoThese surfacing improvements will help to address the defects on this section of the A and will greatly improve the driving experience for motorists.ldquoIt is essential that we close the road during these works to ensure the safety of our road workers and motorists however, wersquove arranged for the project to take place overnight and at weekends to minimise the impact.ldquoWe thank motorists and the local community in advance for their patience and understanding. Wersquoll do all we can to complete the work as quickly and safely as possible.Emergency services and other stakeholders have been consulted in advance and strict physical distancing protocols are in place to protect teams and ensure they remain safe on site, in line with Scottish Government guidance.Real time journey information is available from Traffic Scotland at trafficscotland.org and its Twitter account.

title: tale-doctor-gone-wrong-plot-authors-new-book
story: The murderous story of Dr George Henry Lamson, who is thought to have killed his two brothers-in-law, has been told by Dr Jan Bondeson in Doctor Poison.Dr Lamson, who studied in Edinburgh before going on to run medical practices in England, was eventually caught by police and sentenced to death for the killing of Percy Malcolm John in April .However, Dr Bondeson was convinced ndash as were Lamsonrsquos barrister and police detectives ndash that the doctor had also killed another brother-in-law, Hubert John.Dr Bondeson, from Dunbar, said: ldquoThere was not sufficient evidence to prosecute him because it had happened several years earlier.ldquoDr Lamson had a strange le. He was a morphine addict who destroyed his prospects as a doctor.ldquoHe used to have practices in Rotherfield, where he murdered Hubert, but he had to leave because he was so addicted to morphine.ldquoHe could not handle the practice anymore and moved to Bournemouth and became incapable of running his practice.Dr Bondeson, , is no stranger to writing about gruesome murders.Earlier this year, he told the story of a dozen unsolved murders in London, including that of prostitute Harriet Buswell, who was killed on Christmas Day.It was during the writing of that book, which was reissued this year, that he came across the story of Dr Lamson.Dr Bondeson said: ldquoBack in  or , I wrote a book called Victorian Murders about ious murders in Victorian times.ldquoDr Lamson was one of the cases and I was surprised how much new material could be found about him.ldquoThere had not been a modern study of him in the last  years and it seemed a good idea to remedy that and write a story of Dr Lamson using modern research, as well as files from the National Archives in Kew.Dr Lamson had been a military doctor before taking on the medical practice in Rotherfield, East Sussex.After he married, he gained two brothers-in-law: Hubert, who had tuberculosis, and Percy, who had scoliosis.In , during a family gathering, Hubert died suddenly, with his cause of death listed as pulmonary consumption and amyloid degeneration.Just two years later, Dr Lamson persuaded Percy to swallow a gelatine capsule, with forensic scientists later finding he had been poisoned with the uncommon vegetable toxin aconitine.Dr Lamson was later found guilty of murder and sentenced to death.Dr Bondeson said: ldquoDuring his criminous and wasted le, Dr Lamson had accomplished some good but also much wickedness short and evil had been his days, as he stood on the scaffold counting one or two more seconds, the longest-lasting in his le, waiting for the drop to open.ldquoThe police detectives, and even Lamsonrsquos barrister Montagu Williams, felt certain that Dr Lamson was a double murderer, having poisoned both his brothers-in-law for the sake of profit.ldquoComparing his murderous career with those of the prolic medical killers Palmer and Pritchard, it indeed seems likely that Dr Lamson murdered Hubert John as well and got away with it.

title: poets-dream-greener-planet-feature-climate-summit-glasgow
story: The Rev Jock Steinrsquos poem The World I Want will be part of a unique virtual art exhibition ahead of the crucial climate talks.The -year-old responded to calls earlier this year by charity WWF Scotland for people to share their vision of a greener and fairer Scotland, with the chance of being part of its Great Scottish Canvas exhibition.The virtual exhibition will be shown at COP climate talks in Glasgow, which get under way at the end of the month.Jockrsquos poem was one of hundreds of entries submitted, which were co-judged by Stephanie Straine and Emma Gillespie, curators from the National Galleries of Scotland, and Scots poet Stuart A Paterson.The  selected pieces are now appearing at COP alongside an exclusive poem by author Alexander McCall Smith, who is behind the hugely successful The No.  Ladiesrsquo Detective Agency series, and a book on nature written by former Makar Jackie Kay.The pieces will also be showcased at the COP climate talks.Jock, who lives in Haddington, said: ldquoSomeone said that the world is run by middle-aged people who are invested in maintaining the world as they know it.ldquoWhen we are young, we have ideas and#imagine#all kinds of possibilities, and then we look for a job and become immersed in the world as it is.ldquoNow that I am in my th year, I am growing younger again and want to see the world as it ought to be.Jock, along with we Margaret, was joint locum minister at Cockenzie Old Parish Church before stepping down from the role in .Lang Banks, director at WWF Scotland, was thrilled by the number of submissions for the Great Scottish Canvas, which is supported by players of Peoplersquos Postcode Lottery and the Cruden Foundation.He said: ldquoWe were blown away by the quality of work sent to us, and also delighted that so many people wanted to get creative in sharing their hopes for a fairer, greener Scotland with us.lsquoThe World I WantrsquoI want for Scotland what I want for#all##### the world that congregates in Glasgow soon,#I want commitment, promises fulfilled,##### no hint of#COP-out#.##I want to wake and breath in air thatrsquos clean,##### hear news of oceans cooler, reefs#revived#I want proper recycling, no more#litter##### by the roads, and fewer cars.##I want to listen to the sound of bees,##### strike out the use of harmful#pesticides#I want to ban rare metal batteries,##### and change the way we think of fuel.##I want the poor to drink in safer#places##### water from an unpolluted#well#I want to cut the felling of the forests,##### nurse these frayed and fragile lungs.##I want the can-do spirit of Prince Philip,##### with the nous of David Attenborough#and the voice of youth like Greta Thunberg##### sounding in our public ears.##I want the rich to practise carbon pricing,##### turn their economics right way#up#I want a government that hears my#voice##### no less, no more than any other.##I want to put some money where my mouth is,##### pay for stuff thatrsquos ethically#sourced#I want to buy more eco-friendly products,##### pull my weight, reduce my footprint.##I want the human species to be#modest##### stewards of our home on planet#earth#I want respect for every form of le,##### and start by saying, lsquoYes we can!rsquo#

title: covid-booster-scotland-book-booster-jab
story: It comes after Nicola Sturgeon announced last week that certain groups would receive a third vaccine, referred to as a booster jag, to improve immunity responseto the virus as the winter months approach.Respiratory illnesses and viruses are generally more common in the winter and more easily spread, which has led to experts warning of potential problems linked to Covid.Hospitals in general are busiest over winter as a result of illnesses like the flu, meaning wards are often nearer there full capacity.It is hoped that the booster jab scheme will help to protect those who are most vulnerable to Covid by boosting their antibodies to fight the virus.Heres who is eligible to get a third vaccine and how you can book yours...The following groups are eligible for the booster vaccine in Scotland:All over-s who wereseverely immunosuppressed at the time of their first or second jab, including those with leukeamia, advanced HIV and recent organ transplants, will also receive a third dose of the vaccine, however this is independent from the booster scheme.Threegroups have so far been offered their Covid booster jab:. frontline health and social care workers. care home residents. over-sFrontline health and social care workers can now book their booster via the NHS inform website.Meanwhile, care home residents will be offered their booster alongside their flu jab over the coming days and weeks.Booster jabs are beingrolled out to adults aged  and over and those on the highest risk list.During her Covid update on Tuesday September , Nicola Sturgeon confirmed people in these groups would be notied of their appointments by either their GP or by letter.Remainingeligible groups - all adults over , all those aged  to  with underlying health conditions, adult carers, unpaid and young carers, and adult household contacts of people who are immunosuppressed - will be able to book online in October.According to the NHS Scotland Inform website, theportal for those over  to book their jabs will open "soon".

title: permission-given-security-cameras-dunbar-hostel-claims-made-people-uncomfortable
story: Owners of the Dolphin Inn, Dunbar, installed two cameras to protect guestsrsquo bicycles and sports equipment during their stay.However, when they were asked to apply retrospectively for planning permission for the cameras, complaints were lodged over the ldquointrusive devices.A report by planning officers revealed that three objections were made, with the main grounds being that ldquothe cameras result in an uncomfortable and unpleasant feeling of being overlooked when walking on the public footpath.They were also claimed to overlook neighbouring properties, invade their privacyand ldquoexacerbate the existing situation of those properties being overlooked by windows from the rear of the building.The Dolphin Inn, on the townrsquos Queens Road, had lain empty for years before the boutique hostel opened its doors in July.Offering rooms with access to self-catering facilitiesand dormitory beds, it provides securebike storage at the rear for its guests.Planning officers said that Dunbar Community Council supported the CCTV cameras being put at the back of the hostel, saying they would improve the propertyrsquos security.The officersrsquo report described the cameras as ldquoeyeball style and said that pictures taken from them had been provided by the hotel showing they did not intrude into neighbouring properties.And they ruled that the white cameras were not ldquoalien to the building.They said: ldquoThe two cameras are not intended to directly overlook any parts of the neighbouring residential properties.ldquoFurthermore, the images captured by the two wall-mounted CCTV cameras do not directly overlook any neighbouring garden.Planning permission was granted for the cameras.

title: east-lothian-residents-facing-16-year-wait-allotment
story: A new survey has revealed that East Lothian residents face the longest wait in Scotland for their own vegetablepatch, with only the London Borough of Camden taking longer, at more than  years.Despite moves in the county to free up land for aspiring gardeners, the number of plots in use and slow turnover time meanspeople face long waits.Councillor Norman Hampshire, East Lothian Councilrsquos environment spokesperson, said that the local authority was working with housebuilders to have allotments included in new developments.He said: ldquoWhile East Lothian is an area with many households who have their own garden, we recognise changing trends in the way we live have led to an increase in demand for allotments and this is something that will be reviewed as part of the preparation of the next Local Development Plan.The latest survey, carried out by MyJobQuote, pulled together information from all  local councils in the UK through Freedom of Information requests.It found that, while the national average wait for an allotment was two years and eight months, in East Lothian it was . years.Edinburghrsquos average wait was about eight years.More than, people in the UK are currently waiting for an allotment and thenumber of Google searches for allotments in the UK is now . times higher than before the coronavirus pandemic.Heather Barrigan, from MyJobQuote, said it was clear that allotments had become more sought after in the wake of the Covid- lockdown.She said: ldquoThroughout the pandemic, more people have discovered their love for gardening and growing their own veg. Itrsquos a great way to feel good and spend time outdoors.ldquoWe were surprised some applicants had had to wait for an allotment, but it just shows how high the demand is.East Lothian Council said that its current Local Development Planalready recognised the growing need for allotments in the county and its own websiteacknowledged that local allotment groups in the county had ldquoa y waiting list and a low annual turnover.Mr Hampshire said: ldquoAt the time of the preparation of the LDP, a study was undertaken into the availability of allotments.ldquoArising from this was an identied need for more allotments and so areas were identied through the plan, as part of proposed housing sites.ldquoWhen the sites concerned are built out, more allotments will become available.Councillor Stuart Currie, SNP Group leader, whose ward Musselburgh is home to an allotment association, said: ldquoClearly the Local Development Plan was supposed to improve this situation and I very much hope that the council will seek to ensure that allotment provision identied is being delivered sooner rather than later.

title: hansel-gretel-bruntons-pantomime-2021
story: The live production, written and directed by award-winning writer and theatre maker John Binnie, will run at the Musselburgh theatre from December  to .Johnrsquos work is popular with Brunton audiences, with his  Jack And The Beanstalk and Cinderella, the following year, both well received.In , he wrote and directed Rapunzel The Pantomime ndash a family film enjoyed by many schools and families who viewed it online during the festive period.The Hansel And Gretel creative team includes set and costume designer Robin Mitchell, musical director Tommie Travers, and Amy Robinson as choreographer.Auditions took place in September to recruit the talented young chorus, who will join the professional cast of a few familiar and well-loved faces.Eilidh Weir plays Gretel, with Ross Donnachie as her wee brother Hansel.Experienced panto dame Graham Crammond s in the role of Dame Maisie Nature, with panto baddy Wendy Seager as Witch Wart-Nose.This new production is billed as ldquoa treat full of fun and laughter with oodles of gags, local references, chart hits, outrageous costumes and shouting out.Tickets are available from The Brunton on    or via thebrunton

title: proposal-split-musselburgh-two-elections-makes-no-sense-whatsoever
story: Changes are being considered to the countyrsquos Westminster constituency ndash which until now has exactly matched the county boundaries ndash under proposals being drawn up by The Boundary Commission for Scotland.One of the proposed changes to the electoral map in Scotland is to see Musselburgh residents who live to the west of the River Esk included in the Edinburgh East constituency .That would include areas of the Capital such as Portobello and Duddingston.The rest of the East Lothian constituency would then be renamed East Lothian Coast and would continue to include the part of Musselburgh to the east of the river .But the proposal has met with opposition in the Honest Toun, including from Midlothian North and Musselburgh MSP Colin Beattie, who told the Courier: ldquoThe proposed boundary change for Musselburgh makes no sense whatsoever and has been ill thought through.ldquoThe change would see the town split in two, which I do not believe will be received well by the residents of Musselburgh.ldquoThe town has already seen changes to its political and council boundaries over the years and this change would only lead to confusion.ldquoMusselburgh is one town and should be served by one MP.ldquoI will be submitting my own objection and I would encourage all residents to strongly consider these proposals and give their views also.Irene Tait, chairperson of Musselburgh and Inveresk Community Council, was also not keen on the idea of making changes to the boundaries.She said: ldquoI would be happythey left it as it is.ldquoMusselburgh is a town on its own and has its own unique identity. That should remain.ldquoIt would be negative to split it up ndash it is not what people would want.The proposals were revealed last Thursday, marking the start of an eight-week consultation.For Scotland as a whole, the number of MPs would be cut from  to . Meanwhile, there would  additional MPs in England, eight fewer in Wales and no change in Northern Ireland.Lord Matthews, Deputy Chair of the Boundary Commission for Scotland, said: ldquoI believe this is a promising start to delivering the requirements of the new rules that mean the number of constituencies in Scotland will reduce from  to , and that each mainland constituency must have broadly the same number of electors.ldquoWe have set out proposals which do that and are, we believe, a good implementation of the rules set by Parliament.ldquoThis is the beginning of a process and we now want to hear the views of the public.ldquoWe will reflect on responses to the consultation and make changes where appropriate and where the legislation allows us to do so.ldquoWe strongly encourage voters to make their views heard.At the last General Election in East Lothian, Kenny MacAskill won the seat for the SNP by a majority of , over incumbent Labour MP Martin Whitfield ndash Mr MacAskill has since left the SNP and joined the ALBA Party.The proposed changes would have no effect to the existing Scottish Parliament constituencies, which see Musselburgh, Wallyford and Whitecraig included as part of the Midlothian North and Musselburgh constituency, and the rest of the county in the East Lothian constituency.ConstraintsEast Lothian MP Mr MacAskill said of the proposals: ldquoBoundaries are rightly not set by politicians or their parties.ldquoThere are constraints given the population set for a constituency and the fact that East Lothian is larger.ldquoTherersquos no easy way of cutting and preferably that wouldnrsquot happen. Butitrsquos to proceed, this may be viewed as one of the least worst options.Paul McLennan, MSP for East Lothian, highlighted the connection between East Lothian and the Honest Toun.He said: ldquoI would encourage constituents who have concerns to engage with the consultation.ldquoThe proposed boundary changes will have no effect on the Scottish Parliamentary constituency however, there have always been close links between Musselburgh and the rest of East Lothian, especially at a local government level.ldquoWhatever the outcome, I will continue to work closely with neighbouring politicians on matters that affect us all like transport and local infrastructure.Martin Whitfield, South Scotland MSP, was not a fan of iding Musselburgh.He said: ldquoI appreciate that the Boundary Commission has a dficult task, especially considering East Lothianrsquos rapidly growing population, but iding Musselburgh in two simply makes no sense.ldquoThe proposal would split the East Lothian Council boundary, as well as the ward boundary, breaking local community ties and creating confusion for residents.ldquoI hope that the commission will listen carefully to the views expressed on these initial proposals and reconsider how the boundaries here will be configured.Craig Hoy, fellow South Scotland MSP, queried the renaming of East Lothian to East Lothian Coast.He said: ldquoI am relieved to see that the Boundary Commission are looking at keeping most of East Lothian within the same parliamentary seat.ldquoThis is an ongoing consultation, so over the coming weeks I will be engaging with constituents in East Lothian to get their views on this review.ldquoMusselburgh is not part of the area I represent and so I cannot comment on parliamentary boundaries in that area.ldquoRegarding where in East Lothian, one thing I am confused about is why the Commission have proposed naming the area lsquoEast Lothian Coastrsquo when parts of the seat are over  miles in-land.

title: artist-helps-start-pilgrimage-dunbar-cop26
story: The Dunbar-based arts organisation will be working with the artist for the next year.Her work led the start of the pilgrimage to COP on Sunday.The contemplative walk began at John Muirrsquos Birthplace, on Dunbar High Street, and will make its way through to Glasgow to talk about the crisis of global warming and the need for urgent action.Numerous events along the way will create experiences, thoughts, ideas and sensations for the walkers and all involved.Childrenrsquos events started the day at Lauderdale Park, followed by events by St Annersquos Church and a sensory slow walk to the harbour, where music and readings took place.A performance of the lsquoKeeper of the Soils cloakrsquo, a community work by Natalie, took place in the Battery amphitheatre.The warning beacon was lit before the walk continued to Belhaven Church Hall, lit by LED light, then pilgrimsrsquo soup by Sunny Soups was served before an evening talk.

title: msp-call-small-businesses-east-lothian-sign-national-campaign
story: Small Business Saturday takes place on the first Saturday in December and encourages shoppers to support all types of small businesses.Martin Whitfield, South Scotland MSP, is calling for businesses to take part in the campaign and use it to promote what they offer to local customers.Mr Whitfield, a former East Lothian MP, is also planning to highlight local businesses in the run-up to December .He described the nationwide campaign as ldquoa fantastic opportunity to celebrate and support the vital contribution small businesses make in their local communities and economies.Mr Whitfield said: ldquoAfter the hardships so many businesses have endured through the pandemic, this is an important and welcome opportunity to help give them a boost at this most important time of the year.ldquoThe campaignrsquos efforts to encourage people to shop locally and support small businesses in their locality have always enjoyed great success.To find out more, go to smallbusinesssaturdayuk

title: east-lothian-peeps-past-october-18-22-1996-1971-1921
story: AN EAST Lothian town was hit by an earthquake, according to the front page of the East Lothian Courier on October , .Residents in parts of Musselburgh were shaking in their shoes this week, with three earthquakes, strong enough to show up on the Richter Scale, vibrating their homes.Panic-stricken people sprinted into the street after the strongest tremor on Monday night, frightened by a loud bang which set crockery rattling.Residentsrsquo fears ranged from burglary to a plane crash after their beds moved and pictures swung on the walls.The epicentre of the tremors was just to the south of the town and the lsquoquakes were felt in the Clayknowes and Stoneyhill areas.Houses were shaken and numerous calls were made to the police but there were no reports of injury or damage to property from the relatively minor earthquakes.Julie Donohue, of Denholm Way, said she was awakened by the lsquoquake on Monday night.A HADDINGTON woman made it to the finals of a beauty contest, as was reported in The Haddingtonshire Courier on October , .Haddingtonrsquos entrant in the national lsquoMiss Slimline rsquo competition, Mrs Valerie Neill, has won her way into the final which is to be held in Edinburgh during January at the annual Slimline Club national dinner and dance.There she will compete along with four other slimmers for the prize of pound for a new wardrobe or a trip to Paris or Majorca.After being selected as the Haddington lsquoMiss Slimline,rsquo -year-old Mrs Neill of  Peachdales went forward to the area heat, held in Edinburgh, which she duly won.lsquoPOACHED by Edinburgh youthsrsquo was a headline in The Haddingtonshire Courier on October  .In Haddington Sherf Court, on Monday, William Birrell, apprentice motor body builder,  Lauriston Place, Edinburgh, and John Wilson,  Ferrier Street, Leith, pleaded guilty to having, on th September, trespassed in pursuit of game on Luffness Links.The Fiscal stated that a police constable in plain clothes saw three men on the links working, as he thought, at a rabbit burrow.He kept an eye upon them for some time, and got the assistance of a trapper on the links.When they went towards the men, the latter made off, and crossed to the public road by the Peffer bridge.The men left three cycles behind them.

title: mary-contini-column-dont-cop---make-difference
story: The annual UN climate change conference, the lsquoConference of the Partiesrsquo, will be attended by the countries that signed the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change ndash a treaty that came into force  years ago.World leaders will arrive in Scotland, alongside tens of thousands of negotiators, government representatives, businesses and citizens for  days of talks to reach agreement on how to tackle climate change.However, as some of the key players are already indicating they are not attending, the question arises will it make any dference this time around  Itrsquos no wonder some personages are not amused.If we canrsquot even depend on world leaders to participate and enforce the agreed changes, what use is it you and I doing anything at all  Surely any real effect on global climate is out of our control If we turn it on its head and take a more personal approach, it can make more sense. Being careful about waste, reassessing our use of fuel and changing our shopping habits can have immediate effects. If we all make small changes, it will help our health, our wealth and our planet.In Scotland, we throw away , tonnes of food and drink a year,  per cent of which could have been eaten. We need to take responsibility here.Use dry bread to make breadcrumbs, bruschetta and croutons. Milk, a couple of eggs and some stale bread make bread and butter pudding. No sacrice there. Old bits of cheese grated and hoarded in the freezer make historic cheese on toast. Too many calories  Walk or get on your bike!Try giving up meat and dairy two days a week and substitute with pulses and veg, your food bill will decrease noticeably. Buy loose, seasonal veg locally and make a good pot of soup ndash we do live in the Garden of Scotland after all. Plastic waste will decrease and dinner will taste better.So donrsquot lsquoCOP outrsquo! Join in and make your dference.

title: fly-tipping-near-retail-park-highlighted-community-group
story: Two cases of fly-tipping were highlighted at the grouprsquos meeting last week, with sites off Newton Port and on the A, to the rear of the retail park.Chris McEwan, chairman of the community council, said during the virtual meeting: ldquoThere is still a bit of roadway there that looks like a lay-by and stuff is dumped there over time.Councillor Shamin Akhtar, who represents the town on East Lothian Council, said she would raise the issue with the local authority.

title: works-east-end-north-berwick-high-street-delayed
story: The works on the east side of the High Street, North Berwick, which will be for a -month trial scheme, were due to start on Monday and were to last for no more than two weeks.It is not yet known how long the works will be delayed.Councillor Norman Hampshire, Environment spokesperson, said: ldquoTrades and contractors across the country will be all too aware of shortages of assorted building materials and supplies in recent months."The council has secured enough to begin these works but rather than starting and then possibly having to stop to await further supplies, our Roads Services team have decided to wait for all materials to be available to enable the work to be carried out with minimal disruption.

title: tranent-reach-scottish-cup-third-round-dunbar-taken-replay-haddington-preston-knocked
story: The Belters were - winners in Alloa against Broomhill, the third Lowland League club they have knocked out of the Scottish Cup in the last two seasons, after wins over Edinburgh University and East Stirlingshire last season. Shaun Rutherford and Ben Miller were the Tranent goalscorers this time.Also in the draw for the third round for the first time will be Dunbar United, though the Seasiders still have work to do to ensure they will progress in the competition, after a last-minute Lothian Thistle Hutchison Vale equaliser at New Countess Park made the final score - cancelling out Jamie Devlinrsquos st-minute strike and meaning the two sides will lock horns again next weekend in Edinburgh for a third-round spot.Also in Scottish Cup action were Haddington Athletic and Preston Athletic but both made their exits from the competition, despite excellent efforts.Haddington too suffered last-minute heartache away at former SPFL club Brechin City, now of the Highland League, with a Hi Hi own goal in the final moments giving the hosts a - win after Haddington had led at half-time through a Guy McGarry strike to allow them to dream of what would have been a famous upset.Meanwhile, Preston had to play most of their tie with  men after a first-half red card but made former Junior giants Auchinleck Talbot fight all the way, keeping the score at - until the final few minutes of the match, when two late goals for the West of Scotland League side saw them run out - winners at the Pennypit to progress.The draw for the third round takes place at .pm on Sunday, with the clubs from the Scottish Championship and Scottish League One entering the competition at that stage, meaning Tranent and Dunbar could potentially be drawn against clubs such as Inverness Caledonian Thistle, Kilmarnock and Hamilton Academical.Away from the Scottish Cup, Musselburgh Athletic and Ormiston were both also in knockout action on Saturday.Musselburgh defeated Kennoway Star Hearts - at Olivebank in the East of Scotland Qualying Cup third round but Ormiston lost in the first round of the King Cup, St Andrews United - winners at Recreation Park.

title: edinburgh-christmas-market-2021-opening-dates-times
story: The pandemic may have put a halt to the annual markets last year, but this year they are due back in all their festive glory.Edinburghs markets are famous and see thousands of people flock to Princes Street Gardens to get in on the action.This year will be no dferent, so heres everything you need to know about the Edinburgh Christmas markets ...There are ious markets across the city, which have slightly dferent dates and opening times.The West Princes Street Gardensmarketwill open on Friday November  and run until Saturday January , operating between the hours of am to pm.The George Street eventwill also open on Friday November  until Saturday January from the hours of am to pm.Meanwhile the East Princes Street Gardensmarketwill open at lunchtime on Saturday November .There are markets in three locations in Edinburgh.The West Princes Street Gardens market is accessible from The Mound, Princes Street and Kings Stables Road.The George Street market will take place just up the road on George Street, while the East Princes Street Gardens market can be accessed from Princes Street and Market Street.If you are attending the West Princes Street Gardens or East Princes Street Gardens markets, there is pay and display available onFrederick Street, George Street, Hanover Street and Waterloo Place.For the George Street market, pay and display parking is available onCharlotte Square, Frederick Street, George Street and Hanover Street.There are plenty of transport options to Edinburgh Christmas markets that dont require a car.Waverley train station is located within a -minute walk of all three markets, as is the Edinburgh bus station.AtWest Princes Street Gardens there will be  market stalls,  fairground rides, a bar and the information point and box office.The East Princes Street Gardens will feature  market stalls, the Big Wheel, the Double Carousel, a bar, a box office and information point and toilets.George Street will host an ice rink, three market stalls and a bar.

title: glasgow-christmas-market-2021-opening-dates-times
